1.1:
Luk 1:1 Inasmuch as many have undertaken to compile a narrative of the things that have been accomplished
among us,
1.2:
Luk 1:2 just as those who from the beginning were eyewitnesses and ministers of the word have delivered them
to us,
1.3:
Luk 1:3 it seemed good to me also, having followed all things closely for some time past, to write an orderly
account for you, most excellent Theophilus,
1.4: Luk 1:4 that you may have certainty concerning the things you have been taught.
1.5:
Luk 1:5 In the days of Herod, king of Judea, there was a priest named Zechariah, of the division of Abijah. And
he had a wife from the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.
1.6:
Luk 1:6 And they were both righteous before God, walking blamelessly in all the commandments and statutes of
the Lord.
1.7: Luk 1:7 But they had no child, because Elizabeth was barren, and both were advanced in years.
1.8: Luk 1:8 Now while he was serving as priest before God when his division was on duty,
1.9:
Luk 1:9 according to the custom of the priesthood, he was chosen by lot to enter the temple of the Lord and
burn incense.
1.10: Luk 1:10 And the whole multitude of the people were praying outside at the hour of incense.
1.11: Luk 1:11 And there appeared to him an angel of the Lord standing on the right side of the altar of incense.
1.12: Luk 1:12 And Zechariah was troubled when he saw him, and fear fell upon him.
1.13:
Luk 1:13 But the angel said to him, "Do not be afraid, Zechariah, for your prayer has been heard, and your wife
Elizabeth will bear you a son, and you shall call his name John.
1.14: Luk 1:14 And you will have joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth,
1.15:
Luk 1:15 for he will be great before the Lord. And he must not drink wine or strong drink, and he will be filled
with the Holy Spirit, even from his mother's womb.
1.16: Luk 1:16 And he will turn many of the children of Israel to the Lord their God,
1.17:
Luk 1:17 and he will go before him in the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of the fathers to the
children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just, to make ready for the Lord a people prepared."
1.18:
Luk 1:18 And Zechariah said to the angel, "How shall I know this? For I am an old man, and my wife is
advanced in years."
1.19:
Luk 1:19 And the angel answered him, "I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God, and I was sent to
speak to you and to bring you this good news.
1.20:
Luk 1:20 And behold, you will be silent and unable to speak until the day that these things take place, because
you did not believe my words, which will be fulfilled in their time."
1.21: Luk 1:21 And the people were waiting for Zechariah, and they were wondering at his delay in the temple.
1.22:
Luk 1:22 And when he came out, he was unable to speak to them, and they realized that he had seen a vision
in the temple. And he kept making signs to them and remained mute.
1.23: Luk 1:23 And when his time of service was ended, he went to his home.
1.24: Luk 1:24 After these days his wife Elizabeth conceived, and for five months she kept herself hidden, saying,
1.25:
Luk 1:25 "Thus the Lord has done for me in the days when he looked on me, to take away my reproach among
people."
1.26: Luk 1:26 In the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee named Nazareth,
1.27:
Luk 1:27 to a virgin betrothed to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David. And the virgin's name
was Mary.
1.28: Luk 1:28 And he came to her and said, "Greetings, O favored one, the Lord is with you!"
1.29: Luk 1:29 But she was greatly troubled at the saying, and tried to discern what sort of greeting this might be.
1.30: Luk 1:30 And the angel said to her, "Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.
1.31: Luk 1:31 And behold, you will conceive in your womb and bear a son, and you shall call his name Jesus.
1.32:
Luk 1:32 He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. And the Lord God will give to him the
throne of his father David,
1.33: Luk 1:33 and he will reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of his kingdom there will be no end."
1.34: Luk 1:34 And Mary said to the angel, "How will this be, since I am a virgin?"
1.35:
Luk 1:35 And the angel answered her, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will
overshadow you; therefore the child to be born will be called holy- the Son of God.
1.36:
Luk 1:36 And behold, your relative Elizabeth in her old age has also conceived a son, and this is the sixth month
with her who was called barren.
1.37: Luk 1:37 For nothing will be impossible with God."
1.38:
Luk 1:38 And Mary said, "Behold, I am the servant of the Lord; let it be to me according to your word." And the
angel departed from her.
1.39: Luk 1:39 In those days Mary arose and went with haste into the hill country, to a town in Judah,
1.40: Luk 1:40 and she entered the house of Zechariah and greeted Elizabeth.
1.41:
Luk 1:41 And when Elizabeth heard the greeting of Mary, the baby leaped in her womb. And Elizabeth was filled
with the Holy Spirit,
1.42:
Luk 1:42 and she ex claimed with a loud cry, "Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your
womb!
1.43: Luk 1:43 And why is this granted to me that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
1.44: Luk 1:44 For behold, when the sound of your greeting came to my ears, the baby in my womb leaped for joy.
1.45:
Luk 1:45 And blessed is she who believed that there would be a fulfillment of what was spoken to her from the
Lord."
1.46: Luk 1:46 And Mary said, "My soul magnifies the Lord,
1.47: Luk 1:47 and my spirit rejoices in God my Savior,
1.48:
Luk 1:48 for he has looked on the humble estate of his servant. For behold, from now on all generations will call
me blessed;
1.49: Luk 1:49 for he who is mighty has done great things for me, and holy is his name.
1.50: Luk 1:50 And his mercy is for those who fear him from generation to generation.
1.51: Luk 1:51 He has shown strength with his arm; he has scattered the proud in the thoughts of their hearts;
1.52: Luk 1:52 he has brought down the mighty from their thrones and exalted those of humble estate;
1.53: Luk 1:53 he has filled the hungry with good things, and the rich he has sent empty away.
1.54: Luk 1:54 He has helped his servant Israel, in remembrance of his mercy,
1.55: Luk 1:55 as he spoke to our fathers, to Abraham and to his offspring forever."
1.56: Luk 1:56 And Mary remained with her about three months and returned to her home.
1.57: Luk 1:57 Now the time came for Elizabeth to give birth, and she bore a son.
1.58:
Luk 1:58 And her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown great mercy to her, and they rejoiced
with her.
1.59:
Luk 1:59 And on the eighth day they came to circumcise the child. And they would have called him Zechariah
after his father,
1.60: Luk 1:60 but his mother answered, "No; he shall be called John."
1.61: Luk 1:61 And they said to her, "None of your relatives is called by this name."
1.62: Luk 1:62 And they made signs to his father, inquiring what he wanted him to be called.
1.63: Luk 1:63 And he asked for a writing tablet and wrote, "His name is John." And they all wondered.
1.64: Luk 1:64 And immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue loosed, and he spoke, blessing God.
1.65:
Luk 1:65 And fear came on all their neighbors. And all these things were talked about through all the hill country
of Judea,
1.66:
Luk 1:66 and all who heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, "What then will this child be?" For the hand
of the Lord was with him.
1.67: Luk 1:67 And his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied, saying,
1.68: Luk 1:68 "Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, for he has visited and redeemed his people
1.69: Luk 1:69 and has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of his servant David,
1.70: Luk 1:70 as he spoke by the mouth of his holy prophets from of old,
1.71: Luk 1:71 that we should be saved from our enemies and from the hand of all who hate us;
1.72: Luk 1:72 to show the mercy promised to our fathers and to remember his holy covenant,
1.73: Luk 1:73 the oath that he swore to our father Abraham, to grant us
1.74: Luk 1:74 that we, being delivered from the hand of our enemies, might serve him without fear,
1.75: Luk 1:75 in holiness and righteousness before him all our days.
1.76:
Luk 1:76 And you, child, will be called the prophet of the Most High; for you will go before the Lord to prepare
his ways,
1.77: Luk 1:77 to give knowledge of salvation to his people in the forgiveness of their sins,
1.78: Luk 1:78 because of the tender mercy of our God, whereby the sunrise shall visit us from on high
1.79:
Luk 1:79 to give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the way of
peace."
1.80:
Luk 1:80 And the child grew and became strong in spirit, and he was in the wilderness until the day of his public
appearance to Israel.

2.1: Luk 2:1 In those days a decree went out from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be registered.
2.2: Luk 2:2 This was the first registration when Quirinius was governor of Syria.
2.3: Luk 2:3 And all went to be registered, each to his own town.
2.4:
Luk 2:4 And Joseph also went up from Galilee, from the town of Nazareth, to Judea, to the city of David, which
is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and lineage of David,
2.5: Luk 2:5 to be registered with Mary, his betrothed, who was with child.
2.6: Luk 2:6 And while they were there, the time came for her to give birth.
2.7:
Luk 2:7 And she gave birth to her firstborn son and wrapped him in swaddling cloths and laid him in a manger,
because there was no place for them in the inn.
2.8: Luk 2:8 And in the same region there were shepherds out in the field, keeping watch over their flock by night.
2.9:
Luk 2:9 And an angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they
were filled with fear.
2.10:
Luk 2:10 And the angel said to them, "Fear not, for behold, I bring you good news of a great joy that will be for
all the people.
2.11: Luk 2:11 For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Savior, who is Christ the Lord.
2.12: Luk 2:12 And this will be a sign for you: you will find a baby wrapped in swaddling cloths and lying in a manger."
2.13: Luk 2:13 And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God and saying,
2.14: Luk 2:14 "Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace among those with whom he is pleased!"
2.15:
Luk 2:15 When the angels went away from them into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, "Let us go
over to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has made known to us."
2.16: Luk 2:16 And they went with haste and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby lying in a manger.
2.17: Luk 2:17 And when they saw it, they made known the saying that had been told them concerning this child.
2.18: Luk 2:18 And all who heard it wondered at what the shepherds told them.
2.19: Luk 2:19 But Mary treasured up all these things, pondering them in her heart.
2.20:
Luk 2:20 And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all they had heard and seen, as it had
been told them.
2.21:
Luk 2:21 And at the end of eight days, when he was circumcised, he was called Jesus, the name given by the
angel before he was conceived in the womb.
2.22:
Luk 2:22 And when the time came for their purification according to the Law of Moses, they brought him up to
Jerusalem to present him to the Lord
2.23:
Luk 2:23 (as it is written in the Law of the Lord, "Every male who first opens the womb shall be called holy to the
Lord")
2.24:
Luk 2:24 and to offer a sacrifice according to what is said in the Law of the Lord, "a pair of turtledoves, or two
young pigeons."
2.25:
Luk 2:25 Now there was a man in Jerusalem, whose name was Simeon, and this man was righteous and
devout, waiting for the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him.
2.26:
Luk 2:26 And it had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he would not see death before he had seen the
Lord's Christ.
2.27:
Luk 2:27 And he came in the Spirit into the temple, and when the parents brought in the child Jesus, to do for
him according to the custom of the Law,
2.28: Luk 2:28 he took him up in his arms and blessed God and said,
2.29: Luk 2:29 "Lord, now you are letting your servant depart in peace, according to your word;
2.30: Luk 2:30 for my eyes have seen your salvation
2.31: Luk 2:31 that you have prepared in the presence of all peoples,
2.32: Luk 2:32 a light for revelation to the Gentiles, and for glory to your people Israel."
2.33: Luk 2:33 And his father and his mother marveled at what was said about him.
2.34: Luk 2:34 And Simeon blessed them and said to Mary his mother, "Behold, this child is appointed for the fall andrising of many in Israel, and for a sign that is opposed
2.35:
Luk 2:35 (and a sword will pierce through your own soul also), so that thoughts from many hearts may be
revealed."
2.36:
Luk 2:36 And there was a prophetess, Anna, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was advanced
in years, having lived with her husband seven years from when she was a virgin,
2.37:
Luk 2:37 and then as a widow until she was eighty-four. She did not depart from the temple, worshiping with
fasting and prayer night and day.
2.38:
Luk 2:38 And coming up at that very hour she began to give thanks to God and to speak of him to all who were
waiting for the redemption of Jerusalem.
2.39:
Luk 2:39 And when they had performed everything according to the Law of the Lord, they returned into Galilee,
to their own town of Nazareth.
2.40: Luk 2:40 And the child grew and became strong, filled with wisdom. And the favor of God was upon him.
2.41: Luk 2:41 Now his parents went to Jerusalem every year at the Feast of the Passover.
2.42: Luk 2:42 And when he was twelve years old, they went up according to custom.
2.43:
Luk 2:43 And when the feast was ended, as they were returning, the boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem. His
parents did not know it,
2.44:
Luk 2:44 but supposing him to be in the group they went a day's journey, but then they began to search for him
among their relatives and acquaintances,
2.45: Luk 2:45 and when they did not find him, they returned to Jerusalem, searching for him.
2.46:
Luk 2:46 After three days they found him in the temple, sitting among the teachers, listening to them and asking
them questions.
2.47: Luk 2:47 And all who heard him were amazed at his understanding and his answers.
2.48:
Luk 2:48 And when his parents saw him, they were astonished. And his mother said to him, "Son, why have you
treated us so? Behold, your father and I have been searching for you in great distress."
2.49:
Luk 2:49 And he said to them, "Why were you looking for me? Did you not know that I must be in my Father's
house?"
2.50: Luk 2:50 And they did not understand the saying that he spoke to them.
2.51:
Luk 2:51 And he went down with them and came to Nazareth and was submissive to them. And his mother
treasured up all these things in her heart.
2.52: Luk 2:52 And Jesus increased in wisdom and in stature and in favor with God and man.

3.1:
Luk 3:1 In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judea, and Herod
being tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias
tetrarch of Abilene,
3.2:
Luk 3:2 during the high priesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came to John the son of Zechariah
in the wilderness.
3.3:
Luk 3:3 And he went into all the region around the Jordan, proclaiming a baptism of repentance for the
forgiveness of sins.
3.4:
Luk 3:4 As it is written in the book of the words of Isaiah the prophet, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness:
Prepare the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.
3.5:
Luk 3:5 Every valley shall be filled, and every mountain and hill shall be made low, and the crooked shall
become straight, and the rough places shall become level ways,
3.6: Luk 3:6 and all flesh shall see the salvation of God."
3.7:
Luk 3:7 He said therefore to the crowds that came out to be baptized by him, "You brood of vipers! Who warned
you to flee from the wrath to come?
3.8:
Luk 3:8 Bear fruits in keeping with repentance. And do not begin to say to yourselves, 'We have Abraham as
our father.' For I tell you, God is able from these stones to raise up children for Abraham.
3.9:
Luk 3:9 Even now the axe is laid to the root of the trees. Every tree therefore that does not bear good fruit is cut
down and thrown into the fire."
3.10: Luk 3:10 And the crowds asked him, "What then shall we do?"
3.11:
Luk 3:11 And he answered them, "Whoever has two tunics is to share with him who has none, and whoever has
food is to do likewise."
3.12: Luk 3:12 Tax collectors also came to be baptized and said to him, "Teacher, what shall we do?"
3.13: Luk 3:13 And he said to them, "Collect no more than you are authorized to do."
3.14:
Luk 3:14 Soldiers also asked him, "And we, what shall we do?" And he said to them, "Do not extort money from
anyone by threats or by false accusation, and be content with your wages."
3.15:
Luk 3:15 As the people were in expectation, and all were questioning in their hearts concerning John, whether
he might be the Christ,
3.16:
Luk 3:16 John answered them all, saying, "I baptize you with water, but he who is mightier than I is coming, the
strap of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
3.17:
Luk 3:17 His winnowing fork is in his hand, to clear his threshing floor and to gather the wheat into his barn, but
the chaff he will burn with unquenchable fire."
3.18: Luk 3:18 So with many other exhortations he preached good news to the people.
3.19:
Luk 3:19 But Herod the tetrarch, who had been reproved by him for Herodias, his brother's wife, and for all the
evil things that Herod had done,
3.20: Luk 3:20 added this to them all, that he locked up John in prison.
3.21:
Luk 3:21 Now when all the people were baptized, and when Jesus also had been baptized and was praying, the
heavens were opened,
3.22:
Luk 3:22 and the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form, like a dove; and a voice came from heaven, "You
are my beloved Son; with you I am well pleased."
3.23:
Luk 3:23 Jesus, when he began his ministry, was about thirty years of age, being the son (as was supposed) of
Joseph, the son of Heli,
3.24: Luk 3:24 the son of Matthat, the son of Levi, the son of Melchi, the son of Jannai, the son of Joseph,
3.25: Luk 3:25 the son of Mattathias, the son of Amos, the son of Nahum, the son of Esli, the son of Naggai,
3.26: Luk 3:26 the son of Maath, the son of Mattathias, the son of Semein, the son of Josech, the son of Joda,
3.27: Luk 3:27 the son of Joanan, the son of Rhesa, the son of Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, the son of Neri,
3.28: Luk 3:28 the son of Melchi, the son of Addi, the son of Cosam, the son of Elmadam, the son of Er,
3.29: Luk 3:29 the son of Joshua, the son of Eliezer, the son of Jorim, the son of Matthat, the son of Levi,
3.30: Luk 3:30 the son of Simeon, the son of Judah, the son of Joseph, the son of Jonam, the son of Eliakim,
3.31: Luk 3:31 the son of Melea, the son of Menna, the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan, the son of David,
3.32: Luk 3:32 the son of Jesse, the son of Obed, the son of Boaz, the son of Sala, the son of Nahshon,
3.33:
Luk 3:33 the son of Amminadab, the son of Admin, the son of Arni, the son of Hezron, the son of Perez, the son
of Judah,
3.34: Luk 3:34 the son of Jacob, the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham, the son of Terah, the son of Nahor,
3.35: Luk 3:35 the son of Serug, the son of Reu, the son of Peleg, the son of Eber, the son of Shelah,
3.36: Luk 3:36 the son of Cainan, the son of Arphaxad, the son of Shem, the son of Noah, the son of Lamech,
3.37: Luk 3:37 the son of Methuselah, the son of Enoch, the son of Jared, the son of Mahalaleel, the son of Cainan,
3.38: Luk 3:38 the son of Enos, the son of Seth, the son of Adam, the son of God.

4.1: Luk 4:1 And Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit in the wilderness
4.2:
Luk 4:2 for forty days, being tempted by the devil. And he ate nothing during those days. And when they were
ended, he was hungry.
4.3: Luk 4:3 The devil said to him, "If you are the Son of God, command this stone to become bread."
4.4: Luk 4:4 And Jesus answered him, "It is written, 'Man shall not live by bread alone.'"
4.5: Luk 4:5 And the devil took him up and showed him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time,
4.6:
Luk 4:6 and said to him, "To you I will give all this authority and their glory, for it has been delivered to me, and I
give it to whom I will.
4.7: Luk 4:7 If you, then, will worship me, it will all be yours."
4.8:
Luk 4:8 And Jesus answered him, "It is written, "' You shall worship the Lord your God, and him only shall you
serve.'"
4.9:
Luk 4:9 And he took him to Jerusalem and set him on the pinnacle of the temple and said to him, "If you are the
Son of God, throw yourself down from here,
4.10: Luk 4:10 for it is written, "' He will command his angels concerning you, to guard you,'
4.11: Luk 4:11 and "'On their hands they will bear you up, lest you strike your foot against a stone.'"
4.12: Luk 4:12 And Jesus answered him, "It is said, 'You shall not put the Lord your God to the test.'"
4.13: Luk 4:13 And when the devil had ended every temptation, he departed from him until an opportune time.
4.14:
Luk 4:14 And Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit to Galilee, and a report about him went out through all
the surrounding country.
4.15: Luk 4:15 And he taught in their synagogues, being glorified by all.
4.16:
Luk 4:16 And he came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up. And as was his custom, he went to the
synagogue on the Sabbath day, and he stood up to read.
4.17:
Luk 4:17 And the scroll of the prophet Isaiah was given to him. He unrolled the scroll and found the place where
it was written,
4.18:
Luk 4:18 "The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor. He
has sent me to proclaim liberty to the captives and recovering of sight to the blind, to set at liberty those who are
oppressed,
4.19: Luk 4:19 to proclaim the year of the Lord's favor."
4.20:
Luk 4:20 And he rolled up the scroll and gave it back to the attendant and sat down. And the eyes of all in the
synagogue were fixed on him.
4.21: Luk 4:21 And he began to say to them, "Today this Scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing."
4.22:
Luk 4:22 And all spoke well of him and marveled at the gracious words that were coming from his mouth. And
they said, "Is not this Joseph's son?"
4.23:
Luk 4:23 And he said to them, "Doubtless you will quote to me this proverb, 'Physician, heal yourself.' What we
have heard you did at Capernaum, do here in your hometown as well."
4.24: Luk 4:24 And he said, "Truly, I say to you, no prophet is acceptable in his hometown.
4.25:
Luk 4:25 But in truth, I tell you, there were many widows in Israel in the days of Elijah, when the heavens were
shut up three years and six months, and a great famine came over all the land,
4.26:
Luk 4:26 and Elijah was sent to none of them but only to Zarephath, in the land of Sidon, to a woman who was a
widow.
4.27:
Luk 4:27 And there were many lepers in Israel in the time of the prophet Elisha, and none of them was
cleansed, but only Naaman the Syrian."
4.28: Luk 4:28 When they heard these things, all in the synagogue were filled with wrath.
4.29:
Luk 4:29 And they rose up and drove him out of the town and brought him to the brow of the hill on which their
town was built, so that they could throw him down the cliff.
4.30: Luk 4:30 But passing through their midst, he went away.
4.31: Luk 4:31 And he went down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee. And he was teaching them on the Sabbath,
4.32: Luk 4:32 and they were astonished at his teaching, for his word possessed authority.
4.33:
Luk 4:33 And in the synagogue there was a man who had the spirit of an unclean demon, and he cried out with
a loud voice,
4.34:
Luk 4:34 "Ha! What have you to do with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you
are- the Holy One of God."
4.35:
Luk 4:35 But Jesus rebuked him, saying, "Be silent and come out of him!" And when the demon had thrown him
down in their midst, he came out of him, having done him no harm.
4.36:
Luk 4:36 And they were all amazed and said to one another, "What is this word? For with authority and power
he commands the unclean spirits, and they come out!"
4.37: Luk 4:37 And reports about him went out into every place in the surrounding region.
4.38:
Luk 4:38 And he arose and left the synagogue and entered Simon's house. Now Simon's mother-in-law was ill
with a high fever, and they appealed to him on her behalf.
4.39:
Luk 4:39 And he stood over her and rebuked the fever, and it left her, and immediately she rose and began to
serve them.
4.40:
Luk 4:40 Now when the sun was setting, all those who had any who were sick with various diseases brought
them to him, and he laid his hands on every one of them and healed them.
4.41:
Luk 4:41 And demons also came out of many, crying, "You are the Son of God!" But he rebuked them and
would not allow them to speak, because they knew that he was the Christ.
4.42:
Luk 4:42 And when it was day, he departed and went into a desolate place. And the people sought him and
came to him, and would have kept him from leaving them,
4.43:
Luk 4:43 but he said to them, "I must preach the good news of the kingdom of God to the other towns as well;
for I was sent for this purpose."
4.44: Luk 4:44 And he was preaching in the synagogues of Judea.

5.1:
Luk 5:1 On one occasion, while the crowd was pressing in on him to hear the word of God, he was standing by
the lake of Gennesaret,
5.2: Luk 5:2 and he saw two boats by the lake, but the fishermen had gone out of them and were washing their nets.
5.3:
Luk 5:3 Getting into one of the boats, which was Simon's, he asked him to put out a little from the land. And he
sat down and taught the people from the boat.
5.4:
Luk 5:4 And when he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, "Put out into the deep and let down your nets for
a catch."
5.5:
Luk 5:5 And Simon answered, "Master, we toiled all night and took nothing! But at your word I will let down the
nets."
5.6: Luk 5:6 And when they had done this, they enclosed a large number of fish, and their nets were breaking.
5.7:
Luk 5:7 They signaled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them. And they came and filled both
the boats, so that they began to sink.
5.8:
Luk 5:8 But when Simon Peter saw it, he fell down at Jesus' knees, saying, "Depart from me, for I am a sinful
man, O Lord."
5.9: Luk 5:9 For he and all who were with him were astonished at the catch of fish that they had taken,
5.10:
Luk 5:10 and so also were James and John, sons of Zebedee, who were partners with Simon. And Jesus said
to Simon, "Do not be afraid; from now on you will be catching men."
5.11: Luk 5:11 And when they had brought their boats to land, they left everything and followed him.
5.12:
Luk 5:12 While he was in one of the cities, there came a man full of leprosy. And when he saw Jesus, he fell on
his face and begged him, "Lord, if you will, you can make me clean."
5.13:
Luk 5:13 And Jesus stretched out his hand and touched him, saying, "I will; be clean." And immediately the
leprosy left him.
5.14:
Luk 5:14 And he charged him to tell no one, but "go and show yourself to the priest, and make an offering for
your cleansing, as Moses commanded, for a proof to them."
5.15:
Luk 5:15 But now even more the report about him went abroad, and great crowds gathered to hear him and to
be healed of their infirmities.
5.16: Luk 5:16 But he would withdraw to desolate places and pray.
5.17:
Luk 5:17 On one of those days, as he was teaching, Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting there, who
had come from every village of Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. And the power of the Lord was with him
to heal.
5.18:
Luk 5:18 And behold, some men were bringing on a bed a man who was paralyzed, and they were seeking to
bring him in and lay him before Jesus,
5.19:
Luk 5:19 but finding no way to bring him in, because of the crowd, they went up on the roof and let him down
with his bed through the tiles into the midst before Jesus.
5.20: Luk 5:20 And when he saw their faith, he said, "Man, your sins are forgiven you."
5.21:
Luk 5:21 And the scribes and the Pharisees began to question, saying, "Who is this who speaks blasphemies?
Who can forgive sins but God alone?"
5.22: Luk 5:22 When Jesus perceived their thoughts, he answered them, "Why do you question in your hearts?
5.23: Luk 5:23 Which is easier, to say, 'Your sins are forgiven you,' or to say, 'Rise and walk'?
5.24:
Luk 5:24 But that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins"- he said to the man
who was paralyzed- "I say to you, rise, pick up your bed and go home."
5.25:
Luk 5:25 And immediately he rose up before them and picked up what he had been lying on and went home,
glorifying God.
5.26:
Luk 5:26 And amazement seized them all, and they glorified God and were filled with awe, saying, "We have
seen extraordinary things today."
5.27:
Luk 5:27 After this he went out and saw a tax collector named Levi, sitting at the tax booth. And he said to him,
"Follow me."
5.28: Luk 5:28 And leaving everything, he rose and followed him.
5.29:
Luk 5:29 And Levi made him a great feast in his house, and there was a large company of tax collectors and
others reclining at table with them.
5.30:
Luk 5:30 And the Pharisees and their scribes grumbled at his disciples, saying, "Why do you eat and drink with
tax collectors and sinners?"
5.31: Luk 5:31 And Jesus answered them, "Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick.
5.32: Luk 5:32 I have not come to call the righteous but sinners to repentance."
5.33:
Luk 5:33 And they said to him, "The disciples of John fast often and offer prayers, and so do the disciples of the
Pharisees, but yours eat and drink."
5.34: Luk 5:34 And Jesus said to them, "Can you make wedding guests fast while the bridegroom is with them?
5.35:
Luk 5:35 The days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast in those
days."
5.36:
Luk 5:36 He also told them a parable: "No one tears a piece from a new garment and puts it on an old garment.
If he does, he will tear the new, and the piece from the new will not match the old.
5.37:
Luk 5:37 And no one puts new wine into old wineskins. If he does, the new wine will burst the skins and it will be
spilled, and the skins will be destroyed.
5.38: Luk 5:38 But new wine must be put into fresh wineskins.
5.39: Luk 5:39 And no one after drinking old wine desires new, for he says, 'The old is good.'"

6.1:
Luk 6:1 On a Sabbath, while he was going through the grainfields, his disciples plucked and ate some heads of
grain, rubbing them in their hands.
6.2: Luk 6:2 But some of the Pharisees said, "Why are you doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath?"
6.3:
Luk 6:3 And Jesus answered them, "Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who
were with him:
6.4:
Luk 6:4 how he entered the house of God and took and ate the bread of the Presence, which is not lawful for
any but the priests to eat, and also gave it to those with him?"
6.5: Luk 6:5 And he said to them, "The Son of Man is lord of the Sabbath."
6.6:
Luk 6:6 On another Sabbath, he entered the synagogue and was teaching, and a man was there whose right
hand was withered.
6.7:
Luk 6:7 And the scribes and the Pharisees watched him, to see whether he would heal on the Sabbath, so that
they might find a reason to accuse him.
6.8:
Luk 6:8 But he knew their thoughts, and he said to the man with the withered hand, "Come and stand here."
And he rose and stood there.
6.9:
Luk 6:9 And Jesus said to them, "I ask you, is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do harm, to save life or
to destroy it?"
6.10:
Luk 6:10 And after looking around at them all he said to him, "Stretch out your hand." And he did so, and his
hand was restored.
6.11: Luk 6:11 But they were filled with fury and discussed with one another what they might do to Jesus.
6.12: Luk 6:12 In these days he went out to the mountain to pray, and all night he continued in prayer to God.
6.13: Luk 6:13 And when day came, he called his disciples and chose from them twelve, whom he named apostles:
6.14:
Luk 6:14 Simon, whom he named Peter, and Andrew his brother, and James and John, and Philip, and
Bartholomew,
6.15: Luk 6:15 and Matthew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus, and Simon who was called the Zealot,
6.16: Luk 6:16 and Judas the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.
6.17:
Luk 6:17 And he came down with them and stood on a level place, with a great crowd of his disciples and a
great multitude of people from all Judea and Jerusalem and the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon,
6.18:
Luk 6:18 who came to hear him and to be healed of their diseases. And those who were troubled with unclean
spirits were cured.
6.19: Luk 6:19 And all the crowd sought to touch him, for power came out from him and healed them all.
6.20:
Luk 6:20 And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said: "Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the
kingdom of God.
6.21:
Luk 6:21 "Blessed are you who are hungry now, for you shall be satisfied. "Blessed are you who weep now, for
you shall laugh.
6.22:
Luk 6:22 "Blessed are you when people hate you and when they exclude you and revile you and spurn your
name as evil, on account of the Son of Man!
6.23:
Luk 6:23 Rejoice in that day, and leap for joy, for behold, your reward is great in heaven; for so their fathers did
to the prophets.
6.24: Luk 6:24 "But woe to you who are rich, for you have received your consolation.
6.25:
Luk 6:25 "Woe to you who are full now, for you shall be hungry. "Woe to you who laugh now, for you shall
mourn and weep.
6.26: Luk 6:26 "Woe to you, when all people speak well of you, for so their fathers did to the false prophets.
6.27: Luk 6:27 "But I say to you who hear, Love your enemies, do good to those who hate you,
6.28: Luk 6:28 bless those who curse you, pray for those who abuse you.
6.29:
Luk 6:29 To one who strikes you on the cheek, offer the other also, and from one who takes away your cloak do
not withhold your tunic either.
6.30:
Luk 6:30 Give to everyone who begs from you, and from one who takes away your goods do not demand them
back.
6.31: Luk 6:31 And as you wish that others would do to you, do so to them.
6.32:
Luk 6:32 "If you love those who love you, what benefit is that to you? For even sinners love those who love
them.
6.33:
Luk 6:33 And if you do good to those who do good to you, what benefit is that to you? For even sinners do the
same.
6.34:
Luk 6:34 And if you lend to those from whom you expect to receive, what credit is that to you? Even sinners
lend to sinners, to get back the same amount.
6.35:
Luk 6:35 But love your enemies, and do good, and lend, expecting nothing in return, and your reward will be
great, and you will be sons of the Most High, for he is kind to the ungrateful and the evil.
6.36: Luk 6:36 Be merciful, even as your Father is merciful.
6.37:
Luk 6:37 , "Judge not, and you will not be judged; condemn not, and you will not be condemned; forgive, and
you will be forgiven;
6.38:
Luk 6:38 give, and it will be given to you. Good measure, pressed down, shaken together, running over, will be
put into your lap. For with the measure you use it will be measured back to you."
6.39: Luk 6:39 He also told them a parable: "Can a blind man lead a blind man? Will they not both fall into a pit?
6.40: Luk 6:40 A disciple is not above his teacher, but everyone when he is fully trained will be like his teacher.
6.41:
Luk 6:41 Why do you see the speck that is in your brother's eye, but do not notice the log that is in your own
eye?
6.42:
Luk 6:42 How can you say to your brother, 'Brother, let me take out the speck that is in your eye,' when you
yourself do not see the log that is in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the log out of your own eye, and
then you will see clearly to take out the speck that is in your brother's eye.
6.43: Luk 6:43 "For no good tree bears bad fruit, nor again does a bad tree bear good fruit,
6.44:
Luk 6:44 for each tree is known by its own fruit. For figs are not gathered from thornbushes, nor are grapes
picked from a bramble bush.
6.45: Luk 6:45 The good person out of the good treasure of his heart produces good, and the evil person out of hisevil treasure produces evil, for out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks.
6.46: Luk 6:46 "Why do you call me 'Lord, Lord,' and not do what I tell you?
6.47: Luk 6:47 Everyone who comes to me and hears my words and does them, I will show you what he is like:
6.48:
Luk 6:48 he is like a man building a house, who dug deep and laid the foundation on the rock. And when a flood
arose, the stream broke against that house and could not shake it, because it had been well built.
6.49:
Luk 6:49 But the one who hears and does not do them is like a man who built a house on the ground without a
foundation. When the stream broke against it, immediately it fell, and the ruin of that house was great."

7.1: Luk 7:1 After he had finished all his sayings in the hearing of the people, he entered Capernaum.
7.2: Luk 7:2 Now a centurion had a servant who was sick and at the point of death, who was highly valued by him.
7.3:
Luk 7:3 When the centurion heard about Jesus, he sent to him elders of the Jews, asking him to come and heal
his servant.
7.4:
Luk 7:4 And when they came to Jesus, they pleaded with him earnestly, saying, "He is worthy to have you do
this for him,
7.5: Luk 7:5 for he loves our nation, and he is the one who built us our synagogue."
7.6:
Luk 7:6 And Jesus went with them. When he was not far from the house, the centurion sent friends, saying to
him, "Lord, do not trouble yourself, for I am not worthy to have you come under my roof.
7.7: Luk 7:7 Therefore I did not presume to come to you. But say the word, and let my servant be healed.
7.8:
Luk 7:8 For I too am a man set under authority, with soldiers under me: and I say to one, 'Go,' and he goes; and
to another, 'Come,' and he comes; and to my servant, 'Do this,' and he does it."
7.9:
Luk 7:9 When Jesus heard these things, he marveled at him, and turning to the crowd that followed him, said, "I
tell you, not even in Israel have I found such faith."
7.10: Luk 7:10 And when those who had been sent returned to the house, they found the servant well.
7.11: Luk 7:11 Soon afterward he went to a town called Nain, and his disciples and a great crowd went with him.
7.12:
Luk 7:12 As he drew near to the gate of the town, behold, a man who had died was being carried out, the only
son of his mother, and she was a widow, and a considerable crowd from the town was with her.
7.13: Luk 7:13 And when the Lord saw her, he had compassion on her and said to her, "Do not weep."
7.14:
Luk 7:14 Then he came up and touched the bier, and the bearers stood still. And he said, "Young man, I say to
you, arise."
7.15: Luk 7:15 And the dead man sat up and began to speak, and Jesus gave him to his mother.
7.16:
Luk 7:16 Fear seized them all, and they glorified God, saying, "A great prophet has arisen among us!" and "God
has visited his people!"
7.17: Luk 7:17 And this report about him spread through the whole of Judea and all the surrounding country.
7.18: Luk 7:18 , The disciples of John reported all these things to him. And John,
7.19:
Luk 7:19 calling two of his disciples to him, sent them to the Lord, saying, "Are you the one who is to come, or
shall we look for another?"
7.20:
Luk 7:20 And when the men had come to him, they said, "John the Baptist has sent us to you, saying, 'Are you
the one who is to come, or shall we look for another?'"
7.21:
Luk 7:21 In that hour he healed many people of diseases and plagues and evil spirits, and on many who were
blind he bestowed sight.
7.22:
Luk 7:22 And he answered them, "Go and tell John what you have seen and heard: the blind receive their sight,
the lame walk, lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, the poor have good news
preached to them.
7.23: Luk 7:23 And blessed is the one who is not offended by me."
7.24:
Luk 7:24 When John's messengers had gone, Jesus began to speak to the crowds concerning John: "What did
you go out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken by the wind?
7.25:
Luk 7:25 What then did you go out to see? A man dressed in soft clothing? Behold, those who are dressed in
splendid clothing and live in luxury are in kings' courts.
7.26: Luk 7:26 What then did you go out to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and more than a prophet.
7.27:
Luk 7:27 This is he of whom it is written, "' Behold, I send my messenger before your face, who will prepare your
way before you.'
7.28:
Luk 7:28 I tell you, among those born of women none is greater than John. Yet the one who is least in the
kingdom of God is greater than he."
7.29:
Luk 7:29 ( When all the people heard this, and the tax collectors too, they declared God just, having been
baptized with the baptism of John,
7.30:
Luk 7:30 but the Pharisees and the lawyers rejected the purpose of God for themselves, not having been
baptized by him.)
7.31: Luk 7:31 "To what then shall I compare the people of this generation, and what are they like?
7.32:
Luk 7:32 They are like children sitting in the marketplace and calling to one another, "' We played the flute for
you, and you did not dance; we sang a dirge, and you did not weep.'
7.33: Luk 7:33 For John the Baptist has come eating no bread and drinking no wine, and you say, 'He has a demon.'
7.34:
Luk 7:34 The Son of Man has come eating and drinking, and you say, 'Look at him! A glutton and a drunkard, a
friend of tax collectors and sinners!'
7.35: Luk 7:35 Yet wisdom is justified by all her children."
7.36:
Luk 7:36 One of the Pharisees asked him to eat with him, and he went into the Pharisee's house and took his
place at the table.
7.37:
Luk 7:37 And behold, a woman of the city, who was a sinner, when she learned that he was reclining at table in
the Pharisee's house, brought an alabaster flask of ointment,
7.38:
Luk 7:38 and standing behind him at his feet, weeping, she began to wet his feet with her tears and wiped them
with the hair of her head and kissed his feet and anointed them with the ointment.
7.39:
Luk 7:39 Now when the Pharisee who had invited him saw this, he said to himself, "If this man were a prophet,
he would have known who and what sort of woman this is who is touching him, for she is a sinner."
7.40:
Luk 7:40 And Jesus answering said to him, "Simon, I have something to say to you." And he answered, "Say it,
Teacher."
7.41: Luk 7:41 "A certain moneylender had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.
7.42: Luk 7:42 When they could not pay, he cancelled the debt of both. Now which of them will love him more?"
7.43:
Luk 7:43 Simon answered, "The one, I suppose, for whom he cancelled the larger debt." And he said to him,
"You have judged rightly."
7.44:
Luk 7:44 Then turning toward the woman he said to Simon, "Do you see this woman? I entered your house; you
gave me no water for my feet, but she has wet my feet with her tears and wiped them with her hair.
7.45: Luk 7:45 You gave me no kiss, but from the time I came in she has not ceased to kiss my feet.
7.46: Luk 7:46 You did not anoint my head with oil, but she has anointed my feet with ointment.
7.47:
Luk 7:47 Therefore I tell you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven- for she loved much. But he who is forgiven
little, loves little."
7.48: Luk 7:48 And he said to her, "Your sins are forgiven."
7.49:
Luk 7:49 Then those who were at table with him began to say among themselves, "Who is this, who even
forgives sins?"
7.50: Luk 7:50 And he said to the woman, "Your faith has saved you; go in peace."

8.1:
Luk 8:1 Soon afterward he went on through cities and villages, proclaiming and bringing the good news of the
kingdom of God. And the twelve were with him,
8.2:
Luk 8:2 and also some women who had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities: Mary, called Magdalene, from
whom seven demons had gone out,
8.3:
Luk 8:3 and Joanna, the wife of Chuza, Herod's household manager, and Susanna, and many others, who
provided for them out of their means.
8.4:
Luk 8:4 And when a great crowd was gathering and people from town after town came to him, he said in a
parable:
8.5:
Luk 8:5 "A sower went out to sow his seed. And as he sowed, some fell along the path and was trampled
underfoot, and the birds of the air devoured it.
8.6: Luk 8:6 And some fell on the rock, and as it grew up, it withered away, because it had no moisture.
8.7: Luk 8:7 And some fell among thorns, and the thorns grew up with it and choked it.
8.8:
Luk 8:8 And some fell into good soil and grew and yielded a hundredfold." As he said these things, he called
out, "He who has ears to hear, let him hear."
8.9: Luk 8:9 And when his disciples asked him what this parable meant,
8.10:
Luk 8:10 he said, "To you it has been given to know the secrets of the kingdom of God, but for others they are in
parables, so that 'seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand.'
8.11: Luk 8:11 Now the parable is this: The seed is the word of God.
8.12:
Luk 8:12 The ones along the path are those who have heard. Then the devil comes and takes away the word
from their hearts, so that they may not believe and be saved.
8.13:
Luk 8:13 And the ones on the rock are those who, when they hear the word, receive it with joy. But these have
no root; they believe for a while, and in time of testing fall away.
8.14:
Luk 8:14 And as for what fell among the thorns, they are those who hear, but as they go on their way they are
choked by the cares and riches and pleasures of life, and their fruit does not mature.
8.15:
Luk 8:15 As for that in the good soil, they are those who, hearing the word, hold it fast in an honest and good
heart, and bear fruit with patience.
8.16:
Luk 8:16 , "No one after lighting a lamp covers it with a jar or puts it under a bed, but puts it on a stand, so that
those who enter may see the light.
8.17:
Luk 8:17 For nothing is hidden that will not be made manifest, nor is anything secret that will not be known and
come to light.
8.18: Luk 8:18 Take care then how you hear, for to the one who has, more will be given, and from the one who hasnot, even what he thinks that he has will be taken away."
8.19: Luk 8:19 Then his mother and his brothers came to him, but they could not reach him because of the crowd.
8.20: Luk 8:20 And he was told, "Your mother and your brothers are standing outside, desiring to see you."
8.21: Luk 8:21 But he answered them, "My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God and do it."
8.22:
Luk 8:22 One day he got into a boat with his disciples, and he said to them, "Let us go across to the other side
of the lake." So they set out,
8.23:
Luk 8:23 and as they sailed he fell asleep. And a windstorm came down on the lake, and they were filling with
water and were in danger.
8.24:
Luk 8:24 And they went and woke him, saying, "Master, Master, we are perishing!" And he awoke and rebuked
the wind and the raging waves, and they ceased, and there was a calm.
8.25:
Luk 8:25 He said to them, "Where is your faith?" And they were afraid, and they marveled, saying to one
another, "Who then is this, that he commands even winds and water, and they obey him?"
8.26: Luk 8:26 Then they sailed to the country of the Gerasenes, which is opposite Galilee.
8.27:
Luk 8:27 When Jesus had stepped out on land, there met him a man from the city who had demons. For a long
time he had worn no clothes, and he had not lived in a house but among the tombs.
8.28:
Luk 8:28 When he saw Jesus, he cried out and fell down before him and said with a loud voice, "What have you
to do with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you, do not torment me."
8.29:
Luk 8:29 For he had commanded the unclean spirit to come out of the man. (For many a time it had seized him.
He was kept under guard and bound with chains and shackles, but he would break the bonds and be driven by
the demon into the desert.)
8.30:
Luk 8:30 Jesus then asked him, "What is your name?" And he said, "Legion," for many demons had entered
him.
8.31: Luk 8:31 And they begged him not to command them to depart into the abyss.
8.32:
Luk 8:32 Now a large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside, and they begged him to let them enter
these. So he gave them permission.
8.33:
Luk 8:33 Then the demons came out of the man and entered the pigs, and the herd rushed down the steep
bank into the lake and were drowned.
8.34: Luk 8:34 When the herdsmen saw what had happened, they fled and told it in the city and in the country.
8.35:
Luk 8:35 Then people went out to see what had happened, and they came to Jesus and found the man from
whom the demons had gone, sitting at the feet of Jesus, clothed and in his right mind, and they were afraid.
8.36: Luk 8:36 And those who had seen it told them how the demon-possessed man had been healed.
8.37:
Luk 8:37 Then all the people of the surrounding country of the Gerasenes asked him to depart from them, for
they were seized with great fear. So he got into the boat and returned.
8.38:
Luk 8:38 The man from whom the demons had gone begged that he might be with him, but Jesus sent him
away, saying,
8.39:
Luk 8:39 "Return to your home, and declare how much God has done for you." And he went away, proclaiming
throughout the whole city how much Jesus had done for him.
8.40: Luk 8:40 Now when Jesus returned, the crowd welcomed him, for they were all waiting for him.
8.41:
Luk 8:41 And there came a man named Jairus, who was a ruler of the synagogue. And falling at Jesus' feet, he
implored him to come to his house,
8.42:
Luk 8:42 for he had an only daughter, about twelve years of age, and she was dying. As Jesus went, the people
pressed around him.
8.43:
Luk 8:43 And there was a woman who had had a discharge of blood for twelve years, and though she had spent
all her living on physicians, she could not be healed by anyone.
8.44:
Luk 8:44 She came up behind him and touched the fringe of his garment, and immediately her discharge of
blood ceased.
8.45:
Luk 8:45 And Jesus said, "Who was it that touched me?" When all denied it, Peter said, "Master, the crowds
surround you and are pressing in on you!"
8.46: Luk 8:46 But Jesus said, "Someone touched me, for I perceive that power has gone out from me."
8.47:
Luk 8:47 And when the woman saw that she was not hidden, she came trembling, and falling down before him
declared in the presence of all the people why she had touched him, and how she had been immediately healed.
8.48: Luk 8:48 And he said to her, "Daughter, your faith has made you well; go in peace."
8.49:
Luk 8:49 While he was still speaking, someone from the ruler's house came and said, "Your daughter is dead;
do not trouble the Teacher any more."
8.50: Luk 8:50 But Jesus on hearing this answered him, "Do not fear; only believe, and she will be well."
8.51:
Luk 8:51 And when he came to the house, he allowed no one to enter with him, except Peter and John and
James, and the father and mother of the child.
8.52:
Luk 8:52 And all were weeping and mourning for her, but he said, "Do not weep, for she is not dead but
sleeping."
8.53: Luk 8:53 And they laughed at him, knowing that she was dead.
8.54: Luk 8:54 But taking her by the hand he called, saying, "Child, arise."
8.55:
Luk 8:55 And her spirit returned, and she got up at once. And he directed that something should be given her to
eat.
8.56: Luk 8:56 And her parents were amazed, but he charged them to tell no one what had happened.

9.1:
Luk 9:1 And he called the twelve together and gave them power and authority over all demons and to cure
diseases,
9.2: Luk 9:2 and he sent them out to proclaim the kingdom of God and to heal.
9.3:
Luk 9:3 And he said to them, "Take nothing for your journey, no staff, nor bag, nor bread, nor money; and do not
have two tunics.
9.4: Luk 9:4 And whatever house you enter, stay there, and from there depart.
9.5:
Luk 9:5 And wherever they do not receive you, when you leave that town shake off the dust from your feet as a
testimony against them."
9.6: Luk 9:6 And they departed and went through the villages, preaching the gospel and healing everywhere.
9.7:
Luk 9:7 Now Herod the tetrarch heard about all that was happening, and he was perplexed, because it was said
by some that John had been raised from the dead,
9.8: Luk 9:8 by some that Elijah had appeared, and by others that one of the prophets of old had risen.
9.9:
Luk 9:9 Herod said, "John I beheaded, but who is this about whom I hear such things?" And he sought to see
him.
9.10:
Luk 9:10 On their return the apostles told him all that they had done. And he took them and withdrew apart to a
town called Bethsaida.
9.11:
Luk 9:11 When the crowds learned it, they followed him, and he welcomed them and spoke to them of the
kingdom of God and cured those who had need of healing.
9.12:
Luk 9:12 Now the day began to wear away, and the twelve came and said to him, "Send the crowd away to go
into the surrounding villages and countryside to find lodging and get provisions, for we are here in a desolate
place."
9.13:
Luk 9:13 But he said to them, "You give them something to eat." They said, "We have no more than five loaves
and two fish- unless we are to go and buy food for all these people."
9.14:
Luk 9:14 For there were about five thousand men. And he said to his disciples, "Have them sit down in groups
of about fifty each."
9.15: Luk 9:15 And they did so, and had them all sit down.
9.16:
Luk 9:16 And taking the five loaves and the two fish, he looked up to heaven and said a blessing over them.
Then he broke the loaves and gave them to the disciples to set before the crowd.
9.17:
Luk 9:17 And they all ate and were satisfied. And what was left over was picked up, twelve baskets of broken
pieces.
9.18:
Luk 9:18 Now it happened that as he was praying alone, the disciples were with him. And he asked them, "Who
do the crowds say that I am?"
9.19:
Luk 9:19 And they answered, "John the Baptist. But others say, Elijah, and others, that one of the prophets of
old has risen."
9.20: Luk 9:20 Then he said to them, "But who do you say that I am?" And Peter answered, "The Christ of God."
9.21: Luk 9:21 And he strictly charged and commanded them to tell this to no one,
9.22:
Luk 9:22 saying, "The Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and
scribes, and be killed, and on the third day be raised."
9.23:
Luk 9:23 And he said to all, "If anyone would come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross daily
and follow me.
9.24: Luk 9:24 For whoever would save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake will save it.
9.25: Luk 9:25 For what does it profit a man if he gains the whole world and loses or forfeits himself?
9.26:
Luk 9:26 For whoever is ashamed of me and of my words, of him will the Son of Man be ashamed when he
comes in his glory and the glory of the Father and of the holy angels.
9.27:
Luk 9:27 But I tell you truly, there are some standing here who will not taste death until they see the kingdom of
God."
9.28:
Luk 9:28 Now about eight days after these sayings he took with him Peter and John and James and went up on
the mountain to pray.
9.29:
Luk 9:29 And as he was praying, the appearance of his face was altered, and his clothing became dazzling
white.
9.30: Luk 9:30 And behold, two men were talking with him, Moses and Elijah,
9.31: Luk 9:31 who appeared in glory and spoke of his departure, which he was about to accomplish at Jerusalem.
9.32:
Luk 9:32 Now Peter and those who were with him were heavy with sleep, but when they became fully awake
they saw his glory and the two men who stood with him.
9.33:
Luk 9:33 And as the men were parting from him, Peter said to Jesus, "Master, it is good that we are here. Let us
make three tents, one for you and one for Moses and one for Elijah"- not knowing what he said.
9.34:
Luk 9:34 As he was saying these things, a cloud came and overshadowed them, and they were afraid as they
entered the cloud.
9.35: Luk 9:35 And a voice came out of the cloud, saying, "This is my Son, my Chosen One; listen to him!"
9.36:
Luk 9:36 And when the voice had spoken, Jesus was found alone. And they kept silent and told no one in those
days anything of what they had seen.
9.37: Luk 9:37 On the next day, when they had come down from the mountain, a great crowd met him.
9.38:
Luk 9:38 And behold, a man from the crowd cried out, "Teacher, I beg you to look at my son, for he is my only
child.
9.39:
Luk 9:39 And behold, a spirit seizes him, and he suddenly cries out. It convulses him so that he foams at the
mouth; and shatters him, and will hardly leave him.
9.40: Luk 9:40 And I begged your disciples to cast it out, but they could not."
9.41:
Luk 9:41 Jesus answered, "O faithless and twisted generation, how long am I to be with you and bear with you?
Bring your son here."
9.42:
Luk 9:42 While he was coming, the demon threw him to the ground and convulsed him. But Jesus rebuked the
unclean spirit and healed the boy, and gave him back to his father.
9.43:
Luk 9:43 And all were astonished at the majesty of God. But while they were all marveling at everything he was
doing, Jesus said to his disciples,
9.44: Luk 9:44 "Let these words sink into your ears: The Son of Man is about to be delivered into the hands of men."
9.45:
Luk 9:45 But they did not understand this saying, and it was concealed from them, so that they might not
perceive it. And they were afraid to ask him about this saying.
9.46: Luk 9:46 An argument arose among them as to which of them was the greatest.
9.47: Luk 9:47 But Jesus, knowing the reasoning of their hearts, took a child and put him by his side
9.48:
Luk 9:48 and said to them, "Whoever receives this child in my name receives me, and whoever receives me
receives him who sent me. For he who is least among you all is the one who is great."
9.49:
Luk 9:49 John answered, "Master, we saw someone casting out demons in your name, and we tried to stop
him, because he does not follow with us."
9.50: Luk 9:50 But Jesus said to him, "Do not stop him, for the one who is not against you is for you."
9.51: Luk 9:51 When the days drew near for him to be taken up, he set his face to go to Jerusalem.
9.52:
Luk 9:52 And he sent messengers ahead of him, who went and entered a village of the Samaritans, to make
preparations for him.
9.53: Luk 9:53 But the people did not receive him, because his face was set toward Jerusalem.
9.54:
Luk 9:54 And when his disciples James and John saw it, they said, "Lord, do you want us to tell fire to come
down from heaven and consume them?"
9.55: Luk 9:55 But he turned and rebuked them.
9.56: Luk 9:56 And they went on to another village.
9.57: Luk 9:57 As they were going along the road, someone said to him, "I will follow you wherever you go."
9.58:
Luk 9:58 And Jesus said to him, "Foxes have holes, and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has
nowhere to lay his head."
9.59: Luk 9:59 To another he said, "Follow me." But he said, "Lord, let me first go and bury my father."
9.60:
Luk 9:60 And Jesus said to him, "Leave the dead to bury their own dead. But as for you, go and proclaim the
kingdom of God."
9.61: Luk 9:61 Yet another said, "I will follow you, Lord, but let me first say farewell to those at my home."
9.62: Luk 9:62 Jesus said to him, "No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is fit for the kingdom of God."

10.1:
Luk 10:1 After this the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them on ahead of him, two by two, into every
town and place where he himself was about to go.
10.2:
Luk 10:2 And he said to them, "The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few. Therefore pray earnestly to the
Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into his harvest.
10.3: Luk 10:3 Go your way; behold, I am sending you out as lambs in the midst of wolves.
10.4: Luk 10:4 Carry no moneybag, no knapsack, no sandals, and greet no one on the road.
10.5: Luk 10:5 Whatever house you enter, first say, 'Peace be to this house!'
10.6: Luk 10:6 And if a son of peace is there, your peace will rest upon him. But if not, it will return to you.
10.7:
Luk 10:7 And remain in the same house, eating and drinking what they provide, for the laborer deserves his
wages. Do not go from house to house.
10.8: Luk 10:8 Whenever you enter a town and they receive you, eat what is set before you.
10.9: Luk 10:9 Heal the sick in it and say to them, 'The kingdom of God has come near to you.'
10.10: Luk 10:10 But whenever you enter a town and they do not receive you, go into its streets and say,
10.11: Luk 10:11 'Even the dust of your town that clings to our feet we wipe off against you. Nevertheless know this,that the kingdom of God has come near.'
10.12: Luk 10:12 I tell you, it will be more bearable on that day for Sodom than for that town.
10.13:
Luk 10:13 "Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in
Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.
10.14: Luk 10:14 But it will be more bearable in the judgment for Tyre and Sidon than for you.
10.15: Luk 10:15 And you, Capernaum, will you be exalted to heaven? You shall be brought down to Hades.
10.16:
Luk 10:16 "The one who hears you hears me, and the one who rejects you re jects me, and the one who rejects
me rejects him who sent me."
10.17: Luk 10:17 The seventy-two returned with joy, saying, "Lord, even the demons are subject to us in your name!"
10.18: Luk 10:18 And he said to them, "I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.
10.19:
Luk 10:19 Behold, I have given you authority to tread on serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the
enemy, and nothing shall hurt you.
10.20:
Luk 10:20 Nevertheless, do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject to you, but rejoice that your names are
written in heaven."
10.22:
Luk 10:22 All things have been handed over to me by my Father, and no one knows who the Son is except the
Father, or who the Father is except the Son and anyone to whom the Son chooses to reveal him."
10.23: Luk 10:23 Then turning to the disciples he said privately, "Blessed are the eyes that see what you see!
10.24:
Luk 10:24 For I tell you that many prophets and kings desired to see what you see, and did not see it, and to
hear what you hear, and did not hear it."
10.25:
Luk 10:25 And behold, a lawyer stood up to put him to the test, saying, "Teacher, what shall I do to inherit
eternal life?"
10.26: Luk 10:26 He said to him, "What is written in the Law? How do you read it?"
10.27:
Luk 10:27 And he answered, "You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and
with all your strength and with all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself."
10.28: Luk 10:28 And he said to him, "You have answered correctly; do this, and you will live."
10.29: Luk 10:29 But he, desiring to justify himself, said to Jesus, "And who is my neighbor?"
10.30:
Luk 10:30 Jesus replied, "A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and he fell among robbers, who
stripped him and beat him and departed, leaving him half dead.
10.31:
Luk 10:31 Now by chance a priest was going down that road, and when he saw him he passed by on the other
side.
10.32: Luk 10:32 So likewise a Levite, when he came to the place and saw him, passed by on the other side.
10.33:
Luk 10:33 But a Samaritan, as he journeyed, came to where he was, and when he saw him, he had
compassion.
10.34:
Luk 10:34 He went to him and bound up his wounds, pouring on oil and wine. Then he set him on his own
animal and brought him to an inn and took care of him.
10.35:
Luk 10:35 And the next day he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper, saying, 'Take care of him,
and whatever more you spend, I will repay you when I come back.'
10.36: Luk 10:36 Which of these three, do you think, proved to be a neighbor to the man who fell among the robbers?"
10.37: Luk 10:37 He said, "The one who showed him mercy." And Jesus said to him, "You go, and do likewise."
10.38:
Luk 10:38 Now as they went on their way, Jesus entered a village. And a woman named Martha welcomed him
into her house.
10.39: Luk 10:39 And she had a sister called Mary, who sat at the Lord's feet and listened to his teaching.
10.40:
Luk 10:40 But Martha was distracted with much serving. And she went up to him and said, "Lord, do you not
care that my sister has left me to serve alone? Tell her then to help me."
10.41: Luk 10:41 But the Lord answered her, "Martha, Martha, you are anxious and troubled about many things,
10.42:
Luk 10:42 but one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen the good portion, which will not be taken away from
her."

11.1:
Luk 11:1 Now Jesus was praying in a certain place, and when he finished, one of his disciples said to him,
"Lord, teach us to pray, as John taught his disciples."
11.2: Luk 11:2 And he said to them, "When you pray, say: "Father, hallowed be your name. Your kingdom come.
11.3: Luk 11:3 Give us each day our daily bread,
11.4:
Luk 11:4 and forgive us our sins, for we ourselves forgive everyone who is indebted to us. And lead us not into
temptation."
11.5:
Luk 11:5 And he said to them, "Which of you who has a friend will go to him at midnight and say to him, 'Friend,
lend me three loaves,
11.6: Luk 11:6 for a friend of mine has arrived on a journey, and I have nothing to set before him';
11.7:
Luk 11:7 and he will answer from within, 'Do not bother me; the door is now shut, and my children are with me in
bed. I cannot get up and give you anything'?
11.8:
Luk 11:8 I tell you, though he will not get up and give him anything because he is his friend, yet because of his
impudence he will rise and give him whatever he needs.
11.9:
Luk 11:9 And I tell you, ask, and it will be given to you; seek, and you will find; knock, and it will be opened to
you.
11.10:
Luk 11:10 For everyone who asks receives, and the one who seeks finds, and to the one who knocks it will be
opened.
11.11: Luk 11:11 What father among you, if his son asks for a fish, will instead of a fish give him a serpent;
11.12: Luk 11:12 or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?
11.13:
Luk 11:13 If you then, who are evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the
heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!"
11.14:
Luk 11:14 Now he was casting out a demon that was mute. When the demon had gone out, the mute man
spoke, and the people marveled.
11.15: Luk 11:15 But some of them said, "He casts out demons by Beelze-bul, the prince of demons,"
11.16: Luk 11:16 while others, to test him, kept seeking from him a sign from heaven.
11.17:
Luk 11:17 But he, knowing their thoughts, said to them, "Every kingdom divided against itself is laid waste, and
a divided household falls.
11.18:
Luk 11:18 And if Satan also is divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? For you say that I cast out
demons by Beelzebul.
11.19:
Luk 11:19 And if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore they will be
your judges.
11.20: Luk 11:20 But if it is by the finger of God that I cast out demons, then the kingdom of God has come upon you.
11.21: Luk 11:21 When a strong man, fully armed, guards his own palace, his goods are safe;
11.22:
Luk 11:22 but when one stronger than he attacks him and overcomes him, he takes away his armor in which he
trusted and divides his spoil.
11.23: Luk 11:23 Whoever is not with me is against me, and whoever does not gather with me scatters.
11.24:
Luk 11:24 "When the unclean spirit has gone out of a person, it passes through waterless places seeking rest,
and finding none it says, 'I will return to my house from which I came.'
11.25: Luk 11:25 And when it comes, it finds the house swept and put in order.
11.26:
Luk 11:26 Then it goes and brings seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and dwell there. And
the last state of that person is worse than the first."
11.27:
Luk 11:27 As he said these things, a woman in the crowd raised her voice and said to him, "Blessed is the
womb that bore you, and the breasts at which you nursed!"
11.28: Luk 11:28 But he said, "Blessed rather are those who hear the word of God and keep it!"
11.29:
Luk 11:29 When the crowds were increasing, he began to say, "This generation is an evil generation. It seeks
for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah.
11.30: Luk 11:30 For as Jonah became a sign to the people of Nineveh, so will the Son of Man be to this generation.
11.31:
Luk 11:31 The queen of the South will rise up at the judgment with the men of this generation and condemn
them, for she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and behold, something greater
than Solomon is here.
11.32:
Luk 11:32 The men of Nineveh will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for they
repented at the preaching of Jonah, and behold, something greater than Jonah is here.
11.33:
Luk 11:33 "No one after lighting a lamp puts it in a cellar or under a basket, but on a stand, so that those who
enter may see the light.
11.34:
Luk 11:34 Your eye is the lamp of your body. When your eye is healthy, your whole body is full of light, but when
it is bad, your body is full of darkness.
11.35: Luk 11:35 Therefore be careful lest the light in you be darkness.
11.36:
Luk 11:36 If then your whole body is full of light, having no part dark, it will be wholly bright, as when a lamp with
its rays gives you light."
11.37:
Luk 11:37 While Jesus was speaking, a Pharisee asked him to dine with him, so he went in and reclined at
table.
11.38: Luk 11:38 The Pharisee was astonished to see that he did not first wash before dinner.
11.39:
Luk 11:39 And the Lord said to him, "Now you Pharisees cleanse the outside of the cup and of the dish, but
inside you are full of greed and wickedness.
11.40: Luk 11:40 You fools! Did not he who made the outside make the inside also?
11.41: Luk 11:41 But give as alms those things that are within, and behold, everything is clean for you.
11.42:
Luk 11:42 "But woe to you Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every herb, and neglect justice and the
love of God. These you ought to have done, without neglecting the others.
11.43:
Luk 11:43 Woe to you Pharisees! For you love the best seat in the synagogues and greetings in the
marketplaces.
11.44: Luk 11:44 Woe to you! For you are like unmarked graves, and people walk over them without knowing it."
11.45: Luk 11:45 One of the lawyers answered him, "Teacher, in saying these things you insult us also."
11.46:
Luk 11:46 And he said, "Woe to you lawyers also! For you load people with burdens hard to bear, and you
yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers.
11.47: Luk 11:47 Woe to you! For you build the tombs of the prophets whom your fathers killed.
11.48:
Luk 11:48 So you are witnesses and you consent to the deeds of your fathers, for they killed them, and you
build their tombs.
11.49:
Luk 11:49 Therefore also the Wisdom of God said, 'I will send them prophets and apostles, some of whom they
will kill and persecute,'
11.50:
Luk 11:50 so that the blood of all the prophets, shed from the foundation of the world, may be charged against
this generation,
11.51:
Luk 11:51 from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zechariah, who perished between the altar and the sanctuary.
Yes, I tell you, it will be required of this generation.
11.52:
Luk 11:52 Woe to you lawyers! For you have taken away the key of knowledge. You did not enter yourselves,
and you hindered those who were entering."
11.53:
Luk 11:53 As he went away from there, the scribes and the Pharisees began to press him hard and to provoke
him to speak about many things,
11.54: Luk 11:54 lying in wait for him, to catch him in something he might say.

12.1:
Luk 12:1 In the meantime, when so many thousands of the people had gathered together that they were
trampling one another, he began to say to his disciples first, "Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is
hypocrisy.
12.2: Luk 12:2 Nothing is covered up that will not be revealed, or hidden that will not be known.
12.3:
Luk 12:3 Therefore whatever you have said in the dark shall be heard in the light, and what you have whispered
in private rooms shall be proclaimed on the housetops.
12.4:
Luk 12:4 "I tell you, my friends, do not fear those who kill the body, and after that have nothing more that they
can do.
12.5:
Luk 12:5 But I will warn you whom to fear: fear him who, after he has killed, has authority to cast into hell. Yes, I
tell you, fear him!
12.6: Luk 12:6 Are not five sparrows sold for two pennies? And not one of them is forgotten before God.
12.7:
Luk 12:7 Why, even the hairs of your head are all numbered. Fear not; you are of more value than many
sparrows.
12.8:
Luk 12:8 "And I tell you, everyone who acknowledges me before men, the Son of Man also will acknowledge
before the angels of God,
12.9: Luk 12:9 but the one who denies me before men will be denied before the angels of God.
12.10:
Luk 12:10 And everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but the one who
blasphemes against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
12.11:
Luk 12:11 And when they bring you before the synagogues and the rulers and the authorities, do not be anxious
about how you should defend yourself or what you should say,
12.12: Luk 12:12 for the Holy Spirit will teach you in that very hour what you ought to say."
12.13: Luk 12:13 Someone in the crowd said to him, "Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me."
12.14: Luk 12:14 But he said to him, "Man, who made me a judge or arbitrator over you?"
12.15:
Luk 12:15 And he said to them, "Take care, and be on your guard against all covetousness, for one's life does
not consist in the abundance of his possessions."
12.16: Luk 12:16 And he told them a parable, saying, "The land of a rich man produced plentifully,
12.17: Luk 12:17 and he thought to himself, 'What shall I do, for I have nowhere to store my crops?'
12.18:
Luk 12:18 And he said, 'I will do this: I will tear down my barns and build larger ones, and there I will store all my
grain and my goods.
12.19:
Luk 12:19 And I will say to my soul, Soul, you have ample goods laid up for many years; relax, eat, drink, be
merry.'
12.20:
Luk 12:20 But God said to him, 'Fool! This night your soul is required of you, and the things you have prepared,
whose will they be?'
12.21: Luk 12:21 So is the one who lays up treasure for himself and is not rich toward God."
12.22:
Luk 12:22 And he said to his disciples, "Therefore I tell you, do not be anxious about your life, what you will eat,
nor about your body, what you will put on.
12.23: Luk 12:23 For life is more than food, and the body more than clothing.
12.24:
Luk 12:24 Consider the ravens: they neither sow nor reap, they have neither storehouse nor barn, and yet God
feeds them. Of how much more value are you than the birds!
12.25: Luk 12:25 And which of you by being anxious can add a single hour to his span of life?
12.26: Luk 12:26 If then you are not able to do as small a thing as that, why are you anxious about the rest?
12.27:
Luk 12:27 Consider the lilies, how they grow: they neither toil nor spin, yet I tell you, even Solomon in all his
glory was not arrayed like one of these.
12.28:
Luk 12:28 But if God so clothes the grass, which is alive in the field today, and tomorrow is thrown into the oven,
how much more will he clothe you, O you of little faith!
12.29: Luk 12:29 And do not seek what you are to eat and what you are to drink, nor be worried.
12.30: Luk 12:30 For all the nations of the world seek after these things, and your Father knows that you need them.
12.31: Luk 12:31 Instead, seek his kingdom, and these things will be added to you.
12.32: Luk 12:32 "Fear not, little flock, for it is your Father's good pleasure to give you the kingdom.
12.33:
Luk 12:33 Sell your possessions, and give to the needy. Provide yourselves with moneybags that do not grow
old, with a treasure in the heavens that does not fail, where no thief approaches and no moth destroys.
12.34: Luk 12:34 For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.
12.35: Luk 12:35 "Stay dressed for action and keep your lamps burning,
12.36:
Luk 12:36 and be like men who are waiting for their master to come home from the wedding feast, so that they
may open the door to him at once when he comes and knocks.
12.37:
Luk 12:37 Blessed are those servants whom the master finds awake when he comes. Truly, I say to you, he will
dress himself for service and have them recline at table, and he will come and serve them.
12.38: Luk 12:38 If he comes in the second watch, or in the third, and finds them awake, blessed are those servants!
12.39:
Luk 12:39 But know this, that if the master of the house had known at what hour the thief was coming, he would
not have left his house to be broken into.
12.40: Luk 12:40 You also must be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect."
12.41: Luk 12:41 Peter said, "Lord, are you telling this parable for us or for all?"
12.42:
Luk 12:42 And the Lord said, "Who then is the faithful and wise manager, whom his master will set over his
household, to give them their portion of food at the proper time?
12.43: Luk 12:43 Blessed is that servant whom his master will find so doing when he comes.
12.44: Luk 12:44 Truly, I say to you, he will set him over all his possessions.
12.45:
Luk 12:45 But if that servant says to himself, 'My master is delayed in coming,' and begins to beat the male and
female servants, and to eat and drink and get drunk,
12.46:
Luk 12:46 the master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he does
not know, and will cut him in pieces and put him with the unfaithful.
12.47:
Luk 12:47 And that servant who knew his master's will but did not get ready or act according to his will, will
receive a severe beating.
12.48:
Luk 12:48 But the one who did not know, and did what deserved a beating, will receive a light beating. Everyone
to whom much was given, of him much will be required, and from him to whom they entrusted much, they will
demand the more.
12.49: Luk 12:49 "I came to cast fire on the earth, and would that it were already kindled!
12.50: Luk 12:50 I have a baptism to be baptized with, and how great is my distress until it is accomplished!
12.51: Luk 12:51 Do you think that I have come to give peace on earth? No, I tell you, but rather division.
12.52: Luk 12:52 For from now on in one house there will be five divided, three against two and two against three.
12.53:
Luk 12:53 They will be divided, father against son and son against father, mother against daughter and
daughter against mother, mother-in-law against her daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law against mother-in-law."
12.54:
Luk 12:54 He also said to the crowds, "When you see a cloud rising in the west, you say at once, 'A shower is
coming.' And so it happens.
12.55: Luk 12:55 And when you see the south wind blowing, you say, 'There will be scorching heat,' and it happens.
12.56:
Luk 12:56 You hypocrites! You know how to interpret the appearance of earth and sky, but why do you not know
how to interpret the present time?
