12.57: Luk 12:57 "And why do you not judge for yourselves what is right?
12.58:
Luk 12:58 As you go with your accuser before the magistrate, make an effort to settle with him on the way, lest
he drag you to the judge, and the judge hand you over to the officer, and the officer put you in prison.
12.59: Luk 12:59 I tell you, you will never get out until you have paid the very last penny."

13.1:
Luk 13:1 There were some present at that very time who told him about the Galileans whose blood Pilate had
mingled with their sacrifices.
13.2:
Luk 13:2 And he answered them, "Do you think that these Galileans were worse sinners than all the other
Galileans, because they suffered in this way?
13.3: Luk 13:3 No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all likewise perish.
13.4:
Luk 13:4 Or those eighteen on whom the tower in Siloam fell and killed them: do you think that they were worse
offenders than all the others who lived in Jerusalem?
13.5: Luk 13:5 No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all likewise perish."
13.6:
Luk 13:6 And he told this parable: "A man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard, and he came seeking fruit on it
and found none.
13.7:
Luk 13:7 And he said to the vinedresser, 'Look, for three years now I have come seeking fruit on this fig tree,
and I find none. Cut it down. Why should it use up the ground?'
13.8: Luk 13:8 And he answered him, 'Sir, let it alone this year also, until I dig around it and put on manure.
13.9: Luk 13:9 Then if it should bear fruit next year, well and good; but if not, you can cut it down.'"
13.10: Luk 13:10 Now he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath.
13.11:
Luk 13:11 And there was a woman who had had a disabling spirit for eighteen years. She was bent over and
could not fully straighten herself.
13.12: Luk 13:12 When Jesus saw her, he called her over and said to her, "Woman, you are freed from your disability."
13.13: Luk 13:13 And he laid his hands on her, and immediately she was made straight, and she glorified God.
13.14:
Luk 13:14 But the ruler of the synagogue, indignant because Jesus had healed on the Sabbath, said to the
people, "There are six days in which work ought to be done. Come on those days and be healed, and not on the
Sabbath day."
13.15:
Luk 13:15 Then the Lord answered him, "You hypocrites! Does not each of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or
his donkey from the manger and lead it away to water it?
13.16:
Luk 13:16 And ought not this woman, a daughter of Abraham whom Satan bound for eighteen years, be loosed
from this bond on the Sabbath day?"
13.17:
Luk 13:17 As he said these things, all his adversaries were put to shame, and all the people rejoiced at all the
glorious things that were done by him.
13.18: Luk 13:18 He said therefore, "What is the kingdom of God like? And to what shall I compare it?
13.19:
Luk 13:19 It is like a grain of mustard seed that a man took and sowed in his garden, and it grew and became a
tree, and the birds of the air made nests in its branches."
13.20: Luk 13:20 And again he said, "To what shall I compare the kingdom of God?
13.21: Luk 13:21 It is like leaven that a woman took and hid in three measures of flour, until it was all leavened."
13.22: Luk 13:22 He went on his way through towns and villages, teaching and journeying toward Jerusalem.
13.23: Luk 13:23 And someone said to him, "Lord, will those who are saved be few?" And he said to them,
13.24: Luk 13:24 "Strive to enter through the narrow door. For many, I tell you, will seek to enter and will not be able.
13.25:
Luk 13:25 When once the master of the house has risen and shut the door, and you begin to stand outside and
to knock at the door, saying, 'Lord, open to us,' then he will answer you, 'I do not know where you come from.'
13.26: Luk 13:26 Then you will begin to say, 'We ate and drank in your presence, and you taught in our streets.'
13.27:
Luk 13:27 But he will say, 'I tell you, I do not know where you come from. Depart from me, all you workers of
evil!'
13.28:
Luk 13:28 In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham and Isaac and
Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God but you yourselves cast out.
13.29:
Luk 13:29 And people will come from east and west, and from north and south, and recline at table in the
kingdom of God.
13.30: Luk 13:30 And behold, some are last who will be first, and some are first who will be last."
13.31:
Luk 13:31 At that very hour some Pharisees came and said to him, "Get away from here, for Herod wants to kill
you."
13.32:
Luk 13:32 And he said to them, "Go and tell that fox, 'Behold, I cast out demons and perform cures today and
tomorrow, and the third day I finish my course.
13.33:
Luk 13:33 Nevertheless, I must go on my way today and tomorrow and the day following, for it cannot be that a
prophet should perish away from Jerusalem.'
13.34:
Luk 13:34 O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to it! How
often would I have gathered your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you would
not!
13.35:
Luk 13:35 Behold, your house is forsaken. And I tell you, you will not see me until you say, 'Blessed is he who
comes in the name of the Lord!'"

14.1:
Luk 14:1 One Sabbath, when he went to dine at the house of a ruler of the Pharisees, they were watching him
carefully.
14.2: Luk 14:2 And behold, there was a man before him who had dropsy.
14.3:
Luk 14:3 And Jesus responded to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, "Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or
not?"
14.4: Luk 14:4 But they remained silent. Then he took him and healed him and sent him away.
14.5:
Luk 14:5 And he said to them, "Which of you, having a son or an ox that has fallen into a well on a Sabbath day,
will not immediately pull him out?"
14.6: Luk 14:6 And they could not reply to these things.
14.7: Luk 14:7 Now he told a parable to those who were invited, when he noticed how they chose the places of honor,saying to them,
14.8:
Luk 14:8 "When you are invited by someone to a wedding feast, do not sit down in a place of honor, lest
someone more distinguished than you be invited by him,
14.9:
Luk 14:9 and he who invited you both will come and say to you, 'Give your place to this person,' and then you
will begin with shame to take the lowest place.
14.10:
Luk 14:10 But when you are invited, go and sit in the lowest place, so that when your host comes he may say to
you, 'Friend, move up higher.' Then you will be honored in the presence of all who sit at table with you.
14.11: Luk 14:11 For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted."
14.12:
Luk 14:12 He said also to the man who had invited him, "When you give a dinner or a banquet, do not invite
your friends or your brothers or your relatives or rich neighbors, lest they also invite you in return and you be
repaid.
14.13: Luk 14:13 But when you give a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind,
14.14:
Luk 14:14 and you will be blessed, because they cannot repay you. You will be repaid at the resurrection of the
just."
14.15:
Luk 14:15 When one of those who reclined at table with him heard these things, he said to him, "Blessed is
everyone who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!"
14.16: Luk 14:16 But he said to him, "A man once gave a great banquet and invited many.
14.17:
Luk 14:17 And at the time for the banquet he sent his servant to say to those who had been invited, 'Come, for
everything is now ready.'
14.18:
Luk 14:18 But they all alike began to make excuses. The first said to him, 'I have bought a field, and I must go
out and see it. Please have me excused.'
14.19:
Luk 14:19 And another said, 'I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I go to examine them. Please have me
excused.'
14.20: Luk 14:20 And another said, 'I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.'
14.21:
Luk 14:21 So the servant came and reported these things to his master. Then the master of the house became
angry and said to his servant, 'Go out quickly to the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in the poor and
crippled and blind and lame.'
14.22: Luk 14:22 And the servant said, 'Sir, what you commanded has been done, and still there is room.'
14.23:
Luk 14:23 And the master said to the servant, 'Go out to the highways and hedges and compel people to come
in, that my house may be filled.
14.24: Luk 14:24 For I tell you, none of those men who were invited shall taste my banquet.'"
14.25: Luk 14:25 Now great crowds accompanied him, and he turned and said to them,
14.26:
Luk 14:26 "If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father and mother and wife and children and
brothers and sisters, yes, and even his own life, he cannot be my disciple.
14.27: Luk 14:27 Whoever does not bear his own cross and come after me cannot be my disciple.
14.28:
Luk 14:28 For which of you, desiring to build a tower, does not first sit down and count the cost, whether he has
enough to complete it?
14.29: Luk 14:29 Otherwise, when he has laid a foundation and is not able to finish, all who see it begin to mock him,
14.30: Luk 14:30 saying, 'This man began to build and was not able to finish.'
14.31:
Luk 14:31 Or what king, going out to encounter another king in war, will not sit down first and deliberate whether
he is able with ten thousand to meet him who comes against him with twenty thousand?
14.32: Luk 14:32 And if not, while the other is yet a great way off, he sends a delegation and asks for terms of peace.
14.33: Luk 14:33 So therefore, any one of you who does not renounce all that he has cannot be my disciple.
14.34: Luk 14:34 "Salt is good, but if salt has lost its taste, how shall its saltiness be restored?
14.35:
Luk 14:35 It is of no use either for the soil or for the manure pile. It is thrown away. He who has ears to hear, let
him hear."

15.1: Luk 15:1 Now the tax collectors and sinners were all drawing near to hear him.
15.2: Luk 15:2 And the Pharisees and the scribes grumbled, saying, "This man receives sinners and eats with them."
15.3: Luk 15:3 So he told them this parable:
15.4:
Luk 15:4 "What man of you, having a hundred sheep, if he has lost one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine
in the open country, and go after the one that is lost, until he finds it?
15.5: Luk 15:5 And when he has found it, he lays it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
15.6:
Luk 15:6 And when he comes home, he calls together his friends and his neighbors, saying to them, 'Rejoice
with me, for I have found my sheep that was lost.'
15.7:
Luk 15:7 Just so, I tell you, there will be more joy in heaven over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine
righteous persons who need no repentance.
15.8:
Luk 15:8 "Or what woman, having ten silver coins, if she loses one coin, does not light a lamp and sweep the
house and seek diligently until she finds it?
15.9: Luk 15:9 And when she has found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, 'Rejoice with me, for Ihave found the coin that I had lost.'
15.10: Luk 15:10 Just so, I tell you, there is joy before the angels of God over one sinner who repents."
15.11: Luk 15:11 And he said, "There was a man who had two sons.
15.12:
Luk 15:12 And the younger of them said to his father, 'Father, give me the share of property that is coming to
me.' And he divided his property between them.
15.13:
Luk 15:13 Not many days later, the younger son gathered all he had and took a journey into a far country, and
there he squandered his property in reckless living.
15.14:
Luk 15:14 And when he had spent everything, a severe famine arose in that country, and he began to be in
need.
15.15:
Luk 15:15 So he went and hired himself out to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him into his fields to
feed pigs.
15.16: Luk 15:16 And he was longing to be fed with the pods that the pigs ate, and no one gave him anything.
15.17:
Luk 15:17 "But when he came to himself, he said, 'How many of my father's hired servants have more than
enough bread, but I perish here with hunger!
15.18:
Luk 15:18 I will arise and go to my father, and I will say to him, "Father, I have sinned against heaven and
before you.
15.19: Luk 15:19 I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Treat me as one of your hired servants."'
15.20:
Luk 15:20 And he arose and came to his father. But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and felt
compassion, and ran and embraced him and kissed him.
15.21:
Luk 15:21 And the son said to him, 'Father, I have sinned against heaven and before you. I am no longer worthy
to be called your son.'
15.22:
Luk 15:22 But the father said to his servants, 'Bring quickly the best robe, and put it on him, and put a ring on
his hand, and shoes on his feet.
15.23: Luk 15:23 And bring the fattened calf and kill it, and let us eat and celebrate.
15.24: Luk 15:24 For this my son was dead, and is alive again; he was lost, and is found.' And they began to celebrate.
15.25:
Luk 15:25 "Now his older son was in the field, and as he came and drew near to the house, he heard music and
dancing.
15.26: Luk 15:26 And he called one of the servants and asked what these things meant.
15.27:
Luk 15:27 And he said to him, 'Your brother has come, and your father has killed the fattened calf, because he
has received him back safe and sound.'
15.28: Luk 15:28 But he was angry and refused to go in. His father came out and entreated him,
15.29:
Luk 15:29 but he answered his father, 'Look, these many years I have served you, and I never disobeyed your
command, yet you never gave me a young goat, that I might celebrate with my friends.
15.30:
Luk 15:30 But when this son of yours came, who has devoured your property with prostitutes, you killed the
fattened calf for him!'
15.31: Luk 15:31 And he said to him, 'Son, you are always with me, and all that is mine is yours.
15.32:
Luk 15:32 It was fitting to celebrate and be glad, for this your brother was dead, and is alive; he was lost, and is
found.'"

16.1:
Luk 16:1 He also said to the disciples, "There was a rich man who had a manager, and charges were brought to
him that this man was wasting his possessions.
16.2:
Luk 16:2 And he called him and said to him, 'What is this that I hear about you? Turn in the account of your
management, for you can no longer be manager.'
16.3:
Luk 16:3 And the manager said to himself, 'What shall I do, since my master is taking the management away
from me? I am not strong enough to dig, and I am ashamed to beg.
16.4:
Luk 16:4 I have decided what to do, so that when I am removed from management, people may receive me into
their houses.'
16.5:
Luk 16:5 So, summoning his master's debtors one by one, he said to the first, 'How much do you owe my
master?'
16.6:
Luk 16:6 He said, 'A hundred measures of oil.' He said to him, 'Take your bill, and sit down quickly and write
fifty.'
16.7:
Luk 16:7 Then he said to another, 'And how much do you owe?' He said, 'A hundred measures of wheat.' He
said to him, 'Take your bill, and write eighty.'
16.8:
Luk 16:8 The master commended the dishonest manager for his shrewdness. For the sons of this world are
more shrewd in dealing with their own generation than the sons of light.
16.9:
Luk 16:9 And I tell you, make friends for yourselves by means of unrighteous wealth, so that when it fails they
may receive you into the eternal dwellings.
16.10:
Luk 16:10 "One who is faithful in a very little is also faithful in much, and one who is dishonest in a very little is
also dishonest in much.
16.11: Luk 16:11 If then you have not been faithful in the unrighteous wealth, who will entrust to you the true riches?
16.12: Luk 16:12 And if you have not been faithful in that which is another's, who will give you that which is your own?
16.13:
Luk 16:13 No servant can serve two masters, for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be
devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and money."
16.14: Luk 16:14 The Pharisees, who were lovers of money, heard all these things, and they ridiculed him.
16.15:
Luk 16:15 And he said to them, "You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts.
For what is exalted among men is an abomination in the sight of God.
16.16:
Luk 16:16 "The Law and the Prophets were until John; since then the good news of the kingdom of God is
preached, and everyone forces his way into it.
16.17: Luk 16:17 But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one dot of the Law to become void.
16.18:
Luk 16:18 "Everyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and he who marries a
woman divorced from her husband commits adultery.
16.19:
Luk 16:19 "There was a rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen and who feasted sumptuously every
day.
16.20: Luk 16:20 And at his gate was laid a poor man named Lazarus, covered with sores,
16.21:
Luk 16:21 who desired to be fed with what fell from the rich man's table. Moreover, even the dogs came and
licked his sores.
16.22:
Luk 16:22 The poor man died and was carried by the angels to Abraham's side. The rich man also died and was
buried,
16.23:
Luk 16:23 and in Hades, being in torment, he lifted up his eyes and saw Abraham far off and Lazarus at his
side.
16.24:
Luk 16:24 And he called out, 'Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus to dip the end of his finger
in water and cool my tongue, for I am in anguish in this flame.'
16.25:
Luk 16:25 But Abraham said, 'Child, remember that you in your lifetime received your good things, and Lazarus
in like manner bad things; but now he is comforted here, and you are in anguish.
16.26:
Luk 16:26 And besides all this, between us and you a great chasm has been fixed, in order that those who
would pass from here to you may not be able, and none may cross from there to us.'
16.27: Luk 16:27 And he said, 'Then I beg you, father, to send him to my father's house
16.28: Luk 16:28 for I have five brothers- so that he may warn them, lest they also come into this place of torment.'
16.29: Luk 16:29 But Abraham said, 'They have Moses and the Prophets; let them hear them.'
16.30: Luk 16:30 And he said, 'No, father Abraham, but if someone goes to them from the dead, they will repent.'
16.31:
Luk 16:31 He said to him, 'If they do not hear Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be convinced if
someone should rise from the dead.'"

17.1:
Luk 17:1 And he said to his disciples, "Temptations to sin are sure to come, but woe to the one through whom
they come!
17.2:
Luk 17:2 It would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck and he were cast into the sea than
that he should cause one of these little ones to sin.
17.3: Luk 17:3 Pay attention to yourselves! If your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him,
17.4:
Luk 17:4 and if he sins against you seven times in the day, and turns to you seven times, saying, 'I repent,' you
must forgive him."
17.5: Luk 17:5 The apostles said to the Lord, "Increase our faith!"
17.6:
Luk 17:6 And the Lord said, "If you had faith like a grain of mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree,
'Be uprooted and planted in the sea,' and it would obey you.
17.7:
Luk 17:7 "Will any one of you who has a servant plowing or keeping sheep say to him when he has come in
from the field, 'Come at once and sit down at table'?
17.8:
Luk 17:8 Will he not rather say to him, 'Prepare supper for me, and dress properly, and serve me while I eat and
drink, and afterward you will eat and drink'?
17.9: Luk 17:9 Does he thank the servant because he did what was commanded?
17.10:
Luk 17:10 So you also, when you have done all that you were commanded, say, 'We are unworthy servants; we
have only done what was our duty.'"
17.11: Luk 17:11 On the way to Jerusalem he was passing along between Samaria and Galilee.
17.12: Luk 17:12 And as he entered a village, he was met by ten lepers, who stood at a distance
17.13: Luk 17:13 and lifted up their voices, saying, "Jesus, Master, have mercy on us."
17.14:
Luk 17:14 When he saw them he said to them, "Go and show yourselves to the priests." And as they went they
were cleansed.
17.15: Luk 17:15 Then one of them, when he saw that he was healed, turned back, praising God with a loud voice;
17.16: Luk 17:16 and he fell on his face at Jesus' feet, giving him thanks. Now he was a Samaritan.
17.17: Luk 17:17 Then Jesus answered, "Were not ten cleansed? Where are the nine?
17.18: Luk 17:18 Was no one found to return and give praise to God except this foreigner?"
17.19: Luk 17:19 And he said to him, "Rise and go your way; your faith has made you well."
17.20:
Luk 17:20 Being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, he answered them, "The
kingdom of God is not coming with signs to be observed,
17.21: Luk 17:21 nor will they say, 'Look, here it is!' or 'There!' for behold, the kingdom of God is in the midst of you."
17.22:
Luk 17:22 And he said to the disciples, "The days are coming when you will desire to see one of the days of the
Son of Man, and you will not see it.
17.23: Luk 17:23 And they will say to you, 'Look, there!' or 'Look, here!' Do not go out or follow them.
17.24:
Luk 17:24 For as the lightning flashes and lights up the sky from one side to the other, so will the Son of Man be
in his day.
17.25: Luk 17:25 But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.
17.26: Luk 17:26 Just as it was in the days of Noah, so will it be in the days of the Son of Man.
17.27:
Luk 17:27 They were eating and drinking and marrying and being given in marriage, until the day when Noah
entered the ark, and the flood came and destroyed them all.
17.28:
Luk 17:28 Likewise, just as it was in the days of Lot- they were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting
and building,
17.29:
Luk 17:29 but on the day when Lot went out from Sodom, fire and sulfur rained from heaven and destroyed
them all
17.30: Luk 17:30 so will it be on the day when the Son of Man is revealed.
17.31:
Luk 17:31 On that day, let the one who is on the housetop, with his goods in the house, not come down to take
them away, and likewise let the one who is in the field not turn back.
17.33: Luk 17:33 Whoever seeks to preserve his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life will keep it.
17.34: Luk 17:34 I tell you, in that night there will be two in one bed. One will be taken and the other left.
17.35: Luk 17:35 There will be two women grinding together. One will be taken and the other left."
17.37:
Luk 17:37 And they said to him, "Where, Lord?" He said to them, "Where the corpse is, there the vultures will
gather."

18.1: Luk 18:1 And he told them a parable to the effect that they ought always to pray and not lose heart.
18.2: Luk 18:2 He said, "In a certain city there was a judge who neither feared God nor respected man.
18.3:
Luk 18:3 And there was a widow in that city who kept coming to him and saying, 'Give me justice against my
adversary.'
18.4: Luk 18:4 For a while he refused, but afterward he said to himself, 'Though I neither fear God nor respect man,
18.5:
Luk 18:5 yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will give her justice, so that she will not beat me down by
her continual coming.'"
18.6: Luk 18:6 And the Lord said, "Hear what the unrighteous judge says.
18.7: Luk 18:7 And will not God give justice to his elect, who cry to him day and night?, Will he delay long over them?
18.8:
Luk 18:8 I tell you, he will give justice to them speedily. Nevertheless, when the Son of Man comes, will he find
faith on earth?"
18.9:
Luk 18:9 He also told this parable to some who trusted in themselves that they were righteous, and treated
others with contempt:
18.10: Luk 18:10 "Two men went up into the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.
18.11:
Luk 18:11 The Pharisee, standing by himself, prayed thus: 'God, I thank you that I am not like other men,
extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even like this tax collector.
18.12: Luk 18:12 I fast twice a week; I give tithes of all that I get.'
18.13:
Luk 18:13 But the tax collector, standing far off, would not even lift up his eyes to heaven, but beat his breast,
saying, 'God, be merciful to me, a sinner!'
18.14:
Luk 18:14 I tell you, this man went down to his house justified, rather than the other. For everyone who exalts
himself will be humbled, but the one who humbles himself will be exalted."
18.15:
Luk 18:15 Now they were bringing even infants to him that he might touch them. And when the disciples saw it,
they rebuked them.
18.16:
Luk 18:16 But Jesus called them to him, saying, "Let the children come to me, and do not hinder them, for to
such belongs the kingdom of God.
18.17: Luk 18:17 Truly, I say to you, whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child shall not enter it."
18.18: Luk 18:18 And a ruler asked him, "Good Teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
18.19: Luk 18:19 And Jesus said to him, "Why do you call me good? No one is good except God alone.
18.20:
Luk 18:20 You know the commandments: 'Do not commit adultery, Do not murder, Do not steal, Do not bear
false witness, Honor your father and mother.'"
18.21: Luk 18:21 And he said, "All these I have kept from my youth."
18.22:
Luk 18:22 When Jesus heard this, he said to him, "One thing you still lack. Sell all that you have and distribute
to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me."
18.23: Luk 18:23 But when he heard these things, he became very sad, for he was extremely rich.
18.24:
Luk 18:24 Jesus, looking at him with sadness, said, "How difficult it is for those who have wealth to enter the
kingdom of God!
18.25:
Luk 18:25 For it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to enter the
kingdom of God."
18.26: Luk 18:26 Those who heard it said, "Then who can be saved?"
18.27: Luk 18:27 But he said, "What is impossible with men is possible with God."
18.28: Luk 18:28 And Peter said, "See, we have left our homes and followed you."
18.29:
Luk 18:29 And he said to them, "Truly, I say to you, there is no one who has left house or wife or brothers or
parents or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
18.30: Luk 18:30 who will not receive many times more in this time, and in the age to come eternal life."
18.31:
Luk 18:31 And taking the twelve, he said to them, "See, we are going up to Jerusalem, and everything that is
written about the Son of Man by the prophets will be accomplished.
18.32:
Luk 18:32 For he will be delivered over to the Gentiles and will be mocked and shamefully treated and spit
upon.
18.33: Luk 18:33 And after flogging him, they will kill him, and on the third day he will rise."
18.34:
Luk 18:34 But they understood none of these things. This saying was hidden from them, and they did not grasp
what was said.
18.35: Luk 18:35 As he drew near to Jericho, a blind man was sitting by the roadside begging.
18.36: Luk 18:36 And hearing a crowd going by, he inquired what this meant.
18.37: Luk 18:37 They told him, "Jesus of Nazareth is passing by."
18.38: Luk 18:38 And he cried out, "Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!"
18.39:
Luk 18:39 And those who were in front rebuked him, telling him to be silent. But he cried out all the more, "Son
of David, have mercy on me!"
18.40:
Luk 18:40 And Jesus stopped and commanded him to be brought to him. And when he came near, he asked
him,
18.41: Luk 18:41 "What do you want me to do for you?" He said, "Lord, let me recover my sight."
18.42: Luk 18:42 And Jesus said to him, "Recover your sight; your faith has made you well."
18.43:
Luk 18:43 And immediately he recovered his sight and followed him, glorifying God. And all the people, when
they saw it, gave praise to God.

19.1: Luk 19:1 He entered Jericho and was passing through.
19.2: Luk 19:2 And there was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a chief tax collector and was rich.
19.3:
Luk 19:3 And he was seeking to see who Jesus was, but on account of the crowd he could not, because he was
small of stature.
19.4:
Luk 19:4 So he ran on ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree to see him, for he was about to pass that
way.
19.5:
Luk 19:5 And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him, "Zacchaeus, hurry and come down,
for I must stay at your house today."
19.6: Luk 19:6 So he hurried and came down and received him joyfully.
19.7: Luk 19:7 And when they saw it, they all grumbled, "He has gone in to be the guest of a man who is a sinner."
19.8:
Luk 19:8 And Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, "Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor. And
if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I restore it fourfold."
19.9: Luk 19:9 And Jesus said to him, "Today salvation has come to this house, since he also is a son of Abraham.
19.10: Luk 19:10 For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost."
19.11:
Luk 19:11 As they heard these things, he proceeded to tell a parable, because he was near to Jerusalem, and
because they supposed that the kingdom of God was to appear immediately.
19.12:
Luk 19:12 He said therefore, "A nobleman went into a far country to receive for himself a kingdom and then
return.
19.13:
Luk 19:13 Calling ten of his servants, he gave them ten minas, and said to them, 'Engage in business until I
come.'
19.14:
Luk 19:14 But his citizens hated him and sent a delegation after him, saying, 'We do not want this man to reign
over us.'
19.15:
Luk 19:15 When he returned, having received the kingdom, he ordered these servants to whom he had given
the money to be called to him, that he might know what they had gained by doing business.
19.16: Luk 19:16 The first came before him, saying, 'Lord, your mina has made ten minas more.'
19.17:
Luk 19:17 And he said to him, 'Well done, good servant! Because you have been faithful in a very little, you
shall have authority over ten cities.'
19.18: Luk 19:18 And the second came, saying, 'Lord, your mina has made five minas.'
19.19: Luk 19:19 And he said to him, 'And you are to be over five cities.'
19.20: Luk 19:20 Then another came, saying, 'Lord, here is your mina, which I kept laid away in a handkerchief;
19.21:
Luk 19:21 for I was afraid of you, because you are a severe man. You take what you did not deposit, and reap
what you did not sow.'
19.22:
Luk 19:22 He said to him, 'I will condemn you with your own words, you wicked servant! You knew that I was a
severe man, taking what I did not deposit and reaping what I did not sow?
19.23:
Luk 19:23 Why then did you not put my money in the bank, and at my coming I might have collected it with
interest?'
19.24:
Luk 19:24 And he said to those who stood by, 'Take the mina from him, and give it to the one who has the ten
minas.'
19.25: Luk 19:25 And they said to him, 'Lord, he has ten minas!'
19.26:
Luk 19:26 'I tell you that to everyone who has, more will be given, but from the one who has not, even what he
has will be taken away.
19.27:
Luk 19:27 But as for these enemies of mine, who did not want me to reign over them, bring them here and
slaughter them before me.'"
19.28: Luk 19:28 And when he had said these things, he went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem.
19.29:
Luk 19:29 When he drew near to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount that is called Olivet, he sent two of the
disciples,
19.30:
Luk 19:30 saying, "Go into the village in front of you, where on entering you will find a colt tied, on which no one
has ever yet sat. Untie it and bring it here.
19.31: Luk 19:31 If anyone asks you, 'Why are you untying it?' you shall say this: 'The Lord has need of it.'"
19.32: Luk 19:32 So those who were sent went away and found it just as he had told them.
19.33: Luk 19:33 And as they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, "Why are you untying the colt?"
19.34: Luk 19:34 And they said, "The Lord has need of it."
19.35: Luk 19:35 And they brought it to Jesus, and throwing their cloaks on the colt, they set Jesus on it.
19.36: Luk 19:36 And as he rode along, they spread their cloaks on the road.
19.37:
Luk 19:37 As he was drawing near- already on the way down the Mount of Olives- the whole multitude of his
disciples began to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works that they had seen,
19.38:
Luk 19:38 saying, "Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory in the
highest!"
19.39: Luk 19:39 And some of the Pharisees in the crowd said to him, "Teacher, rebuke your disciples."
19.40: Luk 19:40 He answered, "I tell you, if these were silent, the very stones would cry out."
19.41: Luk 19:41 And when he drew near and saw the city, he wept over it,
19.42:
Luk 19:42 saying, "Would that you, even you, had known on this day the things that make for peace! But now
they are hidden from your eyes.
19.43:
Luk 19:43 For the days will come upon you, when your enemies will set up a barricade around you and
surround you and hem you in on every side
19.44:
Luk 19:44 and tear you down to the ground, you and your children within you. And they will not leave one stone
upon another in you, because you did not know the time of your visitation."
19.45: Luk 19:45 And he entered the temple and began to drive out those who sold,
19.46:
Luk 19:46 saying to them, "It is written, 'My house shall be a house of prayer,' but you have made it a den of
robbers."
19.47:
Luk 19:47 And he was teaching daily in the temple. The chief priests and the scribes and the principal men of
the people were seeking to destroy him,
19.48: Luk 19:48 but they did not find anything they could do, for all the people were hanging on his words.

20.1:
Luk 20:1 One day, as Jesus was teaching the people in the temple and preaching the gospel, the chief priests
and the scribes with the elders came up
20.2:
Luk 20:2 and said to him, "Tell us by what authority you do these things, or who it is that gave you this
authority."
20.3: Luk 20:3 He answered them, "I also will ask you a question. Now tell me,
20.4: Luk 20:4 Was the baptism of John from heaven or from man?"
20.5:
Luk 20:5 And they discussed it with one another, saying, "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say, 'Why did you not
believe him?'
20.6:
Luk 20:6 But if we say, 'From man,' all the people will stone us to death, for they are convinced that John was a
prophet."
20.7: Luk 20:7 So they answered that they did not know where it came from.
20.8: Luk 20:8 And Jesus said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things."
20.9:
Luk 20:9 And he began to tell the people this parable: "A man planted a vineyard and let it out to tenants and
went into another country for a long while.
20.10: Luk 20:10 When the time came, he sent a servant to the tenants, so that they would give him some of the fruit ofthe vineyard. But the tenants beat him and sent him away empty-handed.
20.11:
Luk 20:11 And he sent another servant. But they also beat and treated him shamefully, and sent him away
empty-handed.
20.12: Luk 20:12 And he sent yet a third. This one also they wounded and cast out.
20.13:
Luk 20:13 Then the owner of the vineyard said, 'What shall I do? I will send my beloved son; perhaps they will
respect him.'
20.14:
Luk 20:14 But when the tenants saw him, they said to themselves, 'This is the heir. Let us kill him, so that the
inheritance may be ours.'
20.15:
Luk 20:15 And they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. What then will the owner of the vineyard do to
them?
20.16:
Luk 20:16 He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others." When they heard this, they
said, "Surely not!"
20.17:
Luk 20:17 But he looked directly at them and said, "What then is this that is written: "' The stone that the builders
rejected has become the cornerstone'?
20.18:
Luk 20:18 Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken to pieces, and when it falls on anyone, it will crush
him."
20.19:
Luk 20:19 The scribes and the chief priests sought to lay hands on him at that very hour, for they perceived that
he had told this parable against them, but they feared the people.
20.20:
Luk 20:20 So they watched him and sent spies, who pretended to be sincere, that they might catch him in
something he said, so as to deliver him up to the authority and jurisdiction of the governor.
20.21:
Luk 20:21 So they asked him, "Teacher, we know that you speak and teach rightly, and show no partiality, but
truly teach the way of God.
20.22: Luk 20:22 Is it lawful for us to give tribute to Caesar, or not?"
20.23: Luk 20:23 But he perceived their craftiness, and said to them,
20.24: Luk 20:24 "Show me a denarius. Whose likeness and inscription does it have?" They said, "Caesar's."
20.25:
Luk 20:25 He said to them, "Then render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are
God's."
20.26:
Luk 20:26 And they were not able in the presence of the people to catch him in what he said, but marveling at
his answer they became silent.
20.27: Luk 20:27 There came to him some Sadducees, those who deny that there is a resurrection,
20.28:
Luk 20:28 and they asked him a question, saying, "Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man's brother dies,
having a wife but no children, the man must take the widow and raise up offspring for his brother.
20.29: Luk 20:29 Now there were seven brothers. The first took a wife, and died without children.
20.31: Luk 20:31 and the third took her, and likewise all seven left no children and died.
20.32: Luk 20:32 Afterward the woman also died.
20.33: Luk 20:33 In the resurrection, therefore, whose wife will the woman be? For the seven had her as wife."
20.34: Luk 20:34 And Jesus said to them, "The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage,
20.35:
Luk 20:35 but those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and to the resurrection from the dead
neither marry nor are given in marriage,
20.36:
Luk 20:36 for they cannot die anymore, because they are equal to angels and are sons of God, being sons of
the resurrection.
20.37:
Luk 20:37 But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed, in the passage about the bush, where he calls the
Lord the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob.
20.38: Luk 20:38 Now he is not God of the dead, but of the living, for all live to him."
20.39: Luk 20:39 Then some of the scribes answered, "Teacher, you have spoken well."
20.40: Luk 20:40 For they no longer dared to ask him any question.
20.41: Luk 20:41 But he said to them, "How can they say that the Christ is David's son?
20.42: Luk 20:42 For David himself says in the Book of Psalms, "' The Lord said to my Lord, Sit at my right hand,
20.43: Luk 20:43 until I make your enemies your footstool.'
20.44: Luk 20:44 David thus calls him Lord, so how is he his son?"
20.45: Luk 20:45 And in the hearing of all the people he said to his disciples,
20.46:
Luk 20:46 "Beware of the scribes, who like to walk around in long robes, and love greetings in the marketplaces
and the best seats in the synagogues and the places of honor at feasts,
20.47:
Luk 20:47 who devour widows' houses and for a pretense make long prayers. They will receive the greater
condemnation."

21.1: Luk 21:1 Jesus looked up and saw the rich putting their gifts into the offering box,
21.2: Luk 21:2 and he saw a poor widow put in two small copper coins.
21.3: Luk 21:3 And he said, "Truly, I tell you, this poor widow has put in more than all of them.
21.4: Luk 21:4 For they all contributed out of their abundance, but she out of her poverty put in all she had to live on."
21.5:
Luk 21:5 And while some were speaking of the temple, how it was adorned with noble stones and offerings, he
said,
21.6:
Luk 21:6 "As for these things that you see, the days will come when there will not be left here one stone upon
another that will not be thrown down."
21.7:
Luk 21:7 And they asked him, "Teacher, when will these things be, and what will be the sign when these things
are about to take place?"
21.8:
Luk 21:8 And he said, "See that you are not led astray. For many will come in my name, saying, 'I am he!' and,
'The time is at hand!' Do not go after them.
21.9:
Luk 21:9 And when you hear of wars and tumults, do not be terrified, for these things must first take place, but
the end will not be at once."
21.10: Luk 21:10 Then he said to them, "Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.
21.11:
Luk 21:11 There will be great earthquakes, and in various places famines and pestilences. And there will be
terrors and great signs from heaven.
21.12:
Luk 21:12 But before all this they will lay their hands on you and persecute you, delivering you up to the
synagogues and prisons, and you will be brought before kings and governors for my name's sake.
21.13: Luk 21:13 This will be your opportunity to bear witness.
21.14: Luk 21:14 Settle it therefore in your minds not to meditate beforehand how to answer,
21.15:
Luk 21:15 for I will give you a mouth and wisdom, which none of your adversaries will be able to withstand or
contradict.
21.16:
Luk 21:16 You will be delivered up even by parents and brothers and relatives and friends, and some of you
they will put to death.
21.17: Luk 21:17 You will be hated by all for my name's sake.
21.18: Luk 21:18 But not a hair of your head will perish.
21.19: Luk 21:19 By your endurance you will gain your lives.
21.20: Luk 21:20 "But when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, then know that its desolation has come near.
21.21:
Luk 21:21 Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains, and let those who are inside the city depart,
and let not those who are out in the country enter it,
21.22: Luk 21:22 for these are days of vengeance, to fulfill all that is written.
21.23:
Luk 21:23 Alas for women who are pregnant and for those who are nursing infants in those days! For there will
be great distress upon the earth and wrath against this people.
21.24:
Luk 21:24 They will fall by the edge of the sword and be led captive among all nations, and Jerusalem will be
trampled underfoot by the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.
21.25:
Luk 21:25 "And there will be signs in sun and moon and stars, and on the earth distress of nations in perplexity
because of the roaring of the sea and the waves,
21.26:
Luk 21:26 people fainting with fear and with foreboding of what is coming on the world. For the powers of the
heavens will be shaken.
21.27: Luk 21:27 And then they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
21.28:
Luk 21:28 Now when these things begin to take place, straighten up and raise your heads, because your
redemption is drawing near."
21.29: Luk 21:29 And he told them a parable: "Look at the fig tree, and all the trees.
21.30: Luk 21:30 As soon as they come out in leaf, you see for yourselves and know that the summer is already near.
21.31: Luk 21:31 So also, when you see these things taking place, you know that the kingdom of God is near.
21.32: Luk 21:32 Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all has taken place.
21.33: Luk 21:33 Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.
21.34:
Luk 21:34 "But watch yourselves lest your hearts be weighed down with dissipation and drunkenness and cares
of this life, and that day come upon you suddenly like a trap.
21.35: Luk 21:35 For it will come upon all who dwell on the face of the whole earth.
21.36:
Luk 21:36 But stay awake at all times, praying that you may have strength to escape all these things that are
going to take place, and to stand before the Son of Man."
21.37:
Luk 21:37 And every day he was teaching in the temple, but at night he went out and lodged on the mount
called Olivet.
21.38: Luk 21:38 And early in the morning all the people came to him in the temple to hear him.

22.1: Luk 22:1 Now the Feast of Unleavened Bread drew near, which is called the Passover.
22.2: Luk 22:2 And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking how to put him to death, for they feared the people.
22.3: Luk 22:3 Then Satan entered into Judas called Iscariot, who was of the number of the twelve.
22.4: Luk 22:4 He went away and conferred with the chief priests and officers how he might betray him to them.
22.5: Luk 22:5 And they were glad, and agreed to give him money.
22.6: Luk 22:6 So he consented and sought an opportunity to betray him to them in the absence of a crowd.
22.7: Luk 22:7 Then came the day of Unleavened Bread, on which the Passover lamb had to be sacrificed.
22.8: Luk 22:8 So Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, "Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat it."
22.9: Luk 22:9 They said to him, "Where will you have us prepare it?"
22.10:
Luk 22:10 He said to them, "Behold, when you have entered the city, a man carrying a jar of water will meet
you. Follow him into the house that he enters
22.11:
Luk 22:11 and tell the master of the house, 'The Teacher says to you, Where is the guest room, where I may eat
the Passover with my disciples?'
22.12: Luk 22:12 And he will show you a large upper room furnished; prepare it there."
22.13: Luk 22:13 And they went and found it just as he had told them, and they prepared the Passover.
22.14: Luk 22:14 And when the hour came, he reclined at table, and the apostles with him.
22.15: Luk 22:15 And he said to them, "I have earnestly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
22.16: Luk 22:16 For I tell you I will not eat it until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God."
22.17:
Luk 22:17 And he took a cup, and when he had given thanks he said, "Take this, and divide it among
yourselves.
22.18: Luk 22:18 For I tell you that from now on I will not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes."
22.19:
Luk 22:19 And he took bread, and when he had given thanks, he broke it and gave it to them, saying, "This is
my body, which is given for you. Do this in remembrance of me."
22.20:
Luk 22:20 And likewise the cup after they had eaten, saying, "This cup that is poured out for you is the new
covenant in my blood.
22.21: Luk 22:21 But behold, the hand of him who betrays me is with me on the table.
22.22: Luk 22:22 For the Son of Man goes as it has been determined, but woe to that man by whom he is betrayed!"
22.23: Luk 22:23 And they began to question one another, which of them it could be who was going to do this.
22.24: Luk 22:24 A dispute also arose among them, as to which of them was to be regarded as the greatest.
22.25:
Luk 22:25 And he said to them, "The kings of the Gentiles exercise lordship over them, and those in authority
over them are called benefactors.
22.26:
Luk 22:26 But not so with you. Rather, let the greatest among you become as the youngest, and the leader as
one who serves.
22.27:
Luk 22:27 For who is the greater, one who reclines at table or one who serves? Is it not the one who reclines at
table? But I am among you as the one who serves.
22.28: Luk 22:28 "You are those who have stayed with me in my trials,
22.29: Luk 22:29 and I assign to you, as my Father assigned to me, a kingdom,
22.30:
Luk 22:30 that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of
Israel.
22.31: Luk 22:31 "Simon, Simon, behold, Satan demanded to have you, that he might sift you like wheat,
22.32:
Luk 22:32 but I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail. And when you have turned again, strengthen
your brothers."
22.33: Luk 22:33 Peter said to him, "Lord, I am ready to go with you both to prison and to death."
22.34:
Luk 22:34 Jesus said, "I tell you, Peter, the rooster will not crow this day, until you deny three times that you
know me."
22.35:
Luk 22:35 And he said to them, "When I sent you out with no moneybag or knapsack or sandals, did you lack
anything?" They said, "Nothing."
22.36:
Luk 22:36 He said to them, "But now let the one who has a moneybag take it, and likewise a knapsack. And let
the one who has no sword sell his cloak and buy one.
22.37:
Luk 22:37 For I tell you that this Scripture must be fulfilled in me: 'And he was numbered with the transgressors.'
For what is written about me has its fulfillment."
22.38: Luk 22:38 And they said, "Look, Lord, here are two swords." And he said to them, "It is enough."
22.39:
Luk 22:39 And he came out and went, as was his custom, to the Mount of Olives, and the disciples followed
him.
22.40: Luk 22:40 And when he came to the place, he said to them, "Pray that you may not enter into temptation."
22.41: Luk 22:41 And he withdrew from them about a stone's throw, and knelt down and prayed,
22.42:
Luk 22:42 saying, "Father, if you are willing, remove this cup from me. Nevertheless, not my will, but yours, be
done."
22.43: Luk 22:43 And there appeared to him an angel from heaven, strengthening him.
22.44:
Luk 22:44 And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly; and his sweat became like great drops of blood
falling down to the ground.
22.45: Luk 22:45 And when he rose from prayer, he came to the disciples and found them sleeping for sorrow,
22.46: Luk 22:46 and he said to them, "Why are you sleeping? Rise and pray that you may not enter into temptation."
22.47:
Luk 22:47 While he was still speaking, there came a crowd, and the man called Judas, one of the twelve, was
leading them. He drew near to Jesus to kiss him,
22.48: Luk 22:48 but Jesus said to him, "Judas, would you betray the Son of Man with a kiss?"
22.49:
Luk 22:49 And when those who were around him saw what would follow, they said, "Lord, shall we strike with
the sword?"
22.50: Luk 22:50 And one of them struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his right ear.
22.51: Luk 22:51 But Jesus said, "No more of this!" And he touched his ear and healed him.
22.52:
Luk 22:52 Then Jesus said to the chief priests and officers of the temple and elders, who had come out against
him, "Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs?
22.53:
Luk 22:53 When I was with you day after day in the temple, you did not lay hands on me. But this is your hour,
and the power of darkness."
22.54:
Luk 22:54 Then they seized him and led him away, bringing him into the high priest's house, and Peter was
following at a distance.
22.55:
Luk 22:55 And when they had kindled a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat
down among them.
22.56:
Luk 22:56 Then a servant girl, seeing him as he sat in the light and looking closely at him, said, "This man also
was with him."
22.57: Luk 22:57 But he denied it, saying, "Woman, I do not know him."
22.58:
Luk 22:58 And a little later someone else saw him and said, "You also are one of them." But Peter said, "Man, I
am not."
22.59:
Luk 22:59 And after an interval of about an hour still another insisted, saying, "Certainly this man also was with
him, for he too is a Galilean."
22.60:
Luk 22:60 But Peter said, "Man, I do not know what you are talking about." And immediately, while he was still
speaking, the rooster crowed.
22.61:
Luk 22:61 And the Lord turned and looked at Peter. And Peter remembered the saying of the Lord, how he had
said to him, "Before the rooster crows today, you will deny me three times."
22.62: Luk 22:62 And he went out and wept bitterly.
22.63: Luk 22:63 Now the men who were holding Jesus in custody were mocking him as they beat him.
22.64: Luk 22:64 They also blindfolded him and kept asking him, "Prophesy! Who is it that struck you?"
22.65: Luk 22:65 And they said many other things against him, blaspheming him.
22.66:
Luk 22:66 When day came, the assembly of the elders of the people gathered together, both chief priests and
scribes. And they led him away to their council, and they said,
22.67: Luk 22:67 "If you are the Christ, tell us." But he said to them, "If I tell you, you will not believe,
22.68: Luk 22:68 and if I ask you, you will not answer.
22.69: Luk 22:69 But from now on the Son of Man shall be seated at the right hand of the power of God."
22.70: Luk 22:70 So they all said, "Are you the Son of God, then?" And he said to them, "You say that I am."
22.71: Luk 22:71 Then they said, "What further testimony do we need? We have heard it ourselves from his own lips."

23.1: Luk 23:1 Then the whole company of them arose and brought him before Pilate.
23.2:
Luk 23:2 And they began to accuse him, saying, "We found this man misleading our nation and forbidding us to
give tribute to Caesar, and saying that he himself is Christ, a king."
23.3: Luk 23:3 And Pilate asked him, "Are you the King of the Jews?" And he answered him, "You have said so."
23.4: Luk 23:4 Then Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowds, "I find no guilt in this man."
23.5:
Luk 23:5 But they were urgent, saying, "He stirs up the people, teaching throughout all Judea, from Galilee even
to this place."
23.6: Luk 23:6 When Pilate heard this, he asked whether the man was a Galilean.
23.7:
Luk 23:7 And when he learned that he belonged to Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him over to Herod, who was
himself in Jerusalem at that time.
23.8:
Luk 23:8 When Herod saw Jesus, he was very glad, for he had long desired to see him, because he had heard
about him, and he was hoping to see some sign done by him.
23.9: Luk 23:9 So he questioned him at some length, but he made no answer.
23.10: Luk 23:10 The chief priests and the scribes stood by, vehemently accusing him.
23.11:
Luk 23:11 And Herod with his soldiers treated him with contempt and mocked him. Then, arraying him in
splendid clothing, he sent him back to Pilate.
23.12:
Luk 23:12 And Herod and Pilate became friends with each other that very day, for before this they had been at
enmity with each other.
23.13: Luk 23:13 Pilate then called together the chief priests and the rulers and the people,
23.14:
Luk 23:14 and said to them, "You brought me this man as one who was misleading the people. And after
examining him before you, behold, I did not find this man guilty of any of your charges against him.
23.15: Luk 23:15 Neither did Herod, for he sent him back to us. Look, nothing deserving death has been done by him.
23.16:
Luk 23:16 I will therefore punish and release him."
Luk 23:17
23.17: Luk 23:18 But they all cried out together, "Away with this man, and release to us Barabbas"-
23.18: Luk 23:19 a man who had been thrown into prison for an insurrection started in the city and for murder.
23.19: Luk 23:20 Pilate addressed them once more, desiring to release Jesus,
23.20: Luk 23:21 but they kept shouting, "Crucify, crucify him!"
23.21:
Luk 23:22 A third time he said to them, "Why, what evil has he done? I have found in him no guilt deserving
death. I will therefore punish and release him."
23.22:
Luk 23:23 But they were urgent, demanding with loud cries that he should be crucified. And their voices
prevailed.
23.23: Luk 23:24 So Pilate decided that their demand should be granted.
23.24:
Luk 23:25 He released the man who had been thrown into prison for insurrection and murder, for whom they
asked, but he delivered Jesus over to their will.
23.25:
Luk 23:26 And as they led him away, they seized one Simon of Cyrene, who was coming in from the country,
and laid on him the cross, to carry it behind Jesus.
23.26:
Luk 23:27 And there followed him a great multitude of the people and of women who were mourning and
lamenting for him.
23.27:
Luk 23:28 But turning to them Jesus said, "Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me, but weep for
yourselves and for your children.
23.28:
Luk 23:29 For behold, the days are coming when they will say, 'Blessed are the barren and the wombs that
never bore and the breasts that never nursed!'
23.29: Luk 23:30 Then they will begin to say to the mountains, 'Fall on us,' and to the hills, 'Cover us.'
23.30: Luk 23:31 For if they do these things when the wood is green, what will happen when it is dry?"
23.31: Luk 23:32 Two others, who were criminals, were led away to be put to death with him.
23.32:
Luk 23:33 And when they came to the place that is called The Skull, there they crucified him, and the criminals,
one on his right and one on his left.
23.33:
Luk 23:34 And Jesus said, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do." And they cast lots to divide
his garments.
23.34:
Luk 23:35 And the people stood by, watching, but the rulers scoffed at him, saying, "He saved others; let him
save himself, if he is the Christ of God, his Chosen One!"
23.35: Luk 23:36 The soldiers also mocked him, coming up and offering him sour wine
23.36: Luk 23:37 and saying, "If you are the King of the Jews, save yourself!"
23.37: Luk 23:38 There was also an inscription over him, "This is the King of the Jews."
23.38:
Luk 23:39 One of the criminals who were hanged railed at him, saying, "Are you not the Christ? Save yourself
and us!"
23.39:
Luk 23:40 But the other rebuked him, saying, "Do you not fear God, since you are under the same sentence of
condemnation?
23.40:
Luk 23:41 And we indeed justly, for we are receiving the due reward of our deeds; but this man has done
nothing wrong."
23.41: Luk 23:42 And he said, "Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom."
23.42: Luk 23:43 And he said to him, "Truly, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise."
23.43: Luk 23:44 It was now about the sixth hour, and there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour,
23.44: Luk 23:45 while the sun's light failed. And the curtain of the temple was torn in two.
23.45:
Luk 23:46 Then Jesus, calling out with a loud voice, said, "Father, into your hands I commit my spirit!" And
having said this he breathed his last.
23.46:
Luk 23:47 Now when the centurion saw what had taken place, he praised God, saying, "Certainly this man was
innocent!"
23.47:
Luk 23:48 And all the crowds that had assembled for this spectacle, when they saw what had taken place,
returned home beating their breasts.
23.48:
Luk 23:49 And all his acquaintances and the women who had followed him from Galilee stood at a distance
watching these things.
23.49:
Luk 23:50 Now there was a man named Joseph, from the Jewish town of Arimathea. He was a member of the
council, a good and righteous man,
23.50: Luk 23:51 who had not consented to their decision and action; and he was looking for the kingdom of God.
23.51: Luk 23:52 This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
23.52:
Luk 23:53 Then he took it down and wrapped it in a linen shroud and laid him in a tomb cut in stone, where no
one had ever yet been laid.
23.53: Luk 23:54 It was the day of Preparation, and the Sabbath was beginning.
23.54:
Luk 23:55 The women who had come with him from Galilee followed and saw the tomb and how his body was
laid.
23.55: Luk 23:56 Then they returned and prepared spices and ointments. On the Sabbath they rested according to thecommandment.

24.1:
Luk 24:1 But on the first day of the week, at early dawn, they went to the tomb, taking the spices they had
prepared.
24.2: Luk 24:2 And they found the stone rolled away from the tomb,
24.3: Luk 24:3 but when they went in they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
24.4: Luk 24:4 While they were perplexed about this, behold, two men stood by them in dazzling apparel.
24.5:
Luk 24:5 And as they were frightened and bowed their faces to the ground, the men said to them, "Why do you
seek the living among the dead?
24.6: Luk 24:6 He is not here, but has risen. Remember how he told you, while he was still in Galilee,
24.7:
Luk 24:7 that the Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men and be crucified and on the third
day rise."
24.8: Luk 24:8 And they remembered his words,
24.9: Luk 24:9 and returning from the tomb they told all these things to the eleven and to all the rest.
24.10:
Luk 24:10 Now it was Mary Magdalene and Joanna and Mary the mother of James and the other women with
them who told these things to the apostles,
24.11: Luk 24:11 but these words seemed to them an idle tale, and they did not believe them.
24.12:
Luk 24:12 But Peter rose and ran to the tomb; stooping and looking in, he saw the linen cloths by themselves;
and he went home marveling at what had happened.
24.13:
Luk 24:13 That very day two of them were going to a village named Emmaus, about seven miles from
Jerusalem,
24.14: Luk 24:14 and they were talking with each other about all these things that had happened.
24.15: Luk 24:15 While they were talking and discussing together, Jesus himself drew near and went with them.
24.16: Luk 24:16 But their eyes were kept from recognizing him.
24.17:
Luk 24:17 And he said to them, "What is this conversation that you are holding with each other as you walk?"
And they stood still, looking sad.
24.18:
Luk 24:18 Then one of them, named Cleopas, answered him, "Are you the only visitor to Jerusalem who does
not know the things that have happened there in these days?"
24.19:
Luk 24:19 And he said to them, "What things?" And they said to him, "Concerning Jesus of Nazareth, a man
who was a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people,
24.20: Luk 24:20 and how our chief priests and rulers delivered him up to be condemned to death, and crucified him.
24.21:
Luk 24:21 But we had hoped that he was the one to redeem Israel. Yes, and besides all this, it is now the third
day since these things happened.
24.22: Luk 24:22 Moreover, some women of our company amazed us. They were at the tomb early in the morning,
24.23:
Luk 24:23 and when they did not find his body, they came back saying that they had even seen a vision of
angels, who said that he was alive.
24.24:
Luk 24:24 Some of those who were with us went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said, but him
they did not see."
24.25: Luk 24:25 And he said to them, "O foolish ones, and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have spoken!
24.26: Luk 24:26 Was it not necessary that the Christ should suffer these things and enter into his glory?"
24.27:
Luk 24:27 And beginning with Moses and all the Prophets, he interpreted to them in all the Scriptures the things
concerning himself.
24.28: Luk 24:28 So they drew near to the village to which they were going. He acted as if he were going farther,
24.29:
Luk 24:29 but they urged him strongly, saying, "Stay with us, for it is toward evening and the day is now far
spent." So he went in to stay with them.
24.30: Luk 24:30 When he was at table with them, he took the bread and blessed and broke it and gave it to them.
24.31: Luk 24:31 And their eyes were opened, and they recognized him. And he vanished from their sight.
24.32:
Luk 24:32 They said to each other, "Did not our hearts burn within us while he talked to us on the road, while he
opened to us the Scriptures?"
24.33:
Luk 24:33 And they rose that same hour and returned to Jerusalem. And they found the eleven and those who
were with them gathered together,
24.34: Luk 24:34 saying, "The Lord has risen indeed, and has appeared to Simon!"
24.35:
Luk 24:35 Then they told what had happened on the road, and how he was known to them in the breaking of the
bread.
24.36:
Luk 24:36 As they were talking about these things, Jesus himself stood among them, and said to them, "Peace
to you!"
24.37: Luk 24:37 But they were startled and frightened and thought they saw a spirit.
24.38: Luk 24:38 And he said to them, "Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your hearts?
24.39:
Luk 24:39 See my hands and my feet, that it is I myself. Touch me, and see. For a spirit does not have flesh and
bones as you see that I have."
24.40: Luk 24:40 And when he had said this, he showed them his hands and his feet.
24.41:
Luk 24:41 And while they still disbelieved for joy and were marveling, he said to them, "Have you anything here
to eat?"
24.42: Luk 24:42 They gave him a piece of broiled fish,
24.43: Luk 24:43 and he took it and ate before them.
24.44:
Luk 24:44 Then he said to them, "These are my words that I spoke to you while I was still with you, that
everything written about me in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms must be fulfilled."
24.45: Luk 24:45 Then he opened their minds to understand the Scriptures,
24.46:
Luk 24:46 and said to them, "Thus it is written, that the Christ should suffer and on the third day rise from the
dead,
24.47:
Luk 24:47 and that repentance and forgiveness of sins should be proclaimed in his name to all nations,
beginning from Jerusalem.
24.48: Luk 24:48 You are witnesses of these things.
24.49:
Luk 24:49 And behold, I am sending the promise of my Father upon you. But stay in the city until you are
clothed with power from on high."
24.50: Luk 24:50 Then he led them out as far as Bethany, and lifting up his hands he blessed them.
24.51: Luk 24:51 While he blessed them, he parted from them and was carried up into heaven.
24.52: Luk 24:52 And they worshiped him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,
24.53: Luk 24:53 and were continually in the temple blessing Go
